Hey voyagers,
/trv/ is a slow board, so don't expect immediate responses. CHECK THE CATALOG – you might find threads already discussing topics you're interested in.

Before asking for suggestions, tell /trv/ about your:
>Budget
>Interests
>Level of understanding of the local language(s)
This makes it easier to give quality advice. Of course, keep your posts travel related.

For all other matters:
General culture questions >>>/int/
Politics discussion >>>/pol/
Transportation discussion >>>/n/
Outdoors-related discussion >>>/out/

For more information about safety, planning and other miscellaneous topics, check out the pastebin in the next post:

>muh pickpocketing
The fact that you had to nitpick this proves my point about the city's safety. Yeah, you have to wear a little front pouch when you go out. But it's not a problem because everyone else does it too.

I got used to traveling with one anyway. They keep you from worrying about whether or not your passport fell out of your pocket. In a way, I consider it Barcelona's gift to me. I've never been pickpocketed, and I never will be thanks to my time in the city, no matter what kind of shithole I visit in the future. It's like I popped my cherry and became a real traveler.

Who walks around with a full-sized backpack anyway? Take the taxi from the airport to your accommodation. Leave the bag in your room. Boom, problem solved.

>>2402449
Daytrip to Fuji then proceed to Kyoto and Osaka. Rent a car and drive or bus to Gifu prefecture stopping at Gero, Shirakawa-Go, Magomejuku and do the Nakasendo trail hike. Stop in Takayama too for some Edo period housing and the folk village. Go from Takayama to Nagano and rail back to Tokyo.

This rough itinerary will prevent you from being a complete pleb and you'll actually be glad you did it the moment you get there. It's mind-blowing that you figured you'd only stay in Tokyo for 3 whole weeks.

>Backpacker Ben
https://youtube.com/@BackpackerBen
Brit who has done videos with Bald but is way more likeable and relatable to the average traveler
>Dale Philip
https://youtube.com/@Dale_Philip
One of the more tolerable food guys
>Kurt Caz
https://youtube.com/@KurtCaz
Puts himself in some seriously fucked up places and situations, consistently A+ content
>Super Enthused
https://youtube.com/@SuperEnthused
One of the only bearable theme park vloggers with a lot of subscribers. I mostly only watch her non-disney uploads.
Grimmlifecollective:
https://youtube.com/@grimmlifecollective
Goth freaks but interesting vids & niche movie-related sights
Hidden gem channels:
>My Expat Diary:
https://youtube.com/@MyExpatDiary
German vlogger who comes off as genuine/authentic and has honest opinions
>Kyde & Eric
https://youtube.com/@kydeanderic
US expats living in Japan. Have 700+ vlogs covering most of the country. Can sometimes be annoying but not too bad.
>Near From Home
https://youtube.com/@NearFromHome
Best Germany channel
>Jacob the Carpetbagger
https://youtube.com/@TheCarpetbagger
Best US roadside attractions channel on YouTube. Can be obnoxious but you get used to it after a few videos.
Nobodies but showing promise:
>Obscurist Tourist
https://youtube.com/@ObscuristTourist
US vlogger/roadside tourism
>Ray Out There
https://youtube.com/@RayOutThere
boring personality but decent roadside vlogs
>Roadside Explorers
https://youtube.com/@RoadsideExplorers
Their vlogs arent that well shot but their content is curated very well for kitsch culture/Americana. Great docs of defunct shit from around the US.

>>2400922
It has probably one of the best and more comprehensive public mass transit systems in the country, but that really isn't saying much. Regional Rail is the best by far, and is pretty consistent in service, but I don't think you'd be using it that much if you were trying to stay specifically in the city.

The rapid transit/City Transit is hit or miss. The Market-Frankford Line's "dangerous" reputation is, in my opinion, heavily overblown by yuppie progtard fags from Germantown who have never been exposed to the debauchery of an urban environment before. Mind your own business, don't cause a scene, and chances are you'll be fine.

I'm not a fan of the busses though, and I would avoid them if I were you. The main issue I have is that they're incredibly inconsistent and can often show up pretty lane.

>t. Philly native
I can answer other more specific questions about the City if any Anon wants.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2401599
Bishkek is a comfortable city to live in as an expat. Small, but big enough that it's got most everything you could want, plus beautiful mountains less than an hour away. Kyrgyzstan is just lovely in general.

In Kazakhstan I in Ust Kamenogorsk, a provincial city whose economy is based on metallurgy and mining. The atmosphere was completely different from Bishkek. It's 50% Russian and 50% Kazakh, and even the Kazakhs are quite Russified. The city is closer culturally and geographically to the cities of southwestern Siberia than Central Asia. There's a huge wealth gap and most people are in poor health because of pollution from heavy industry. The city itself doesnt have much charm. However, East Kazakhstan as a whole is a fascinating place with plenty of beautiful landscapes and interesting people. It's right where the steppe meets the Altai, so there's plenty to explore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402145
It's very easy. You only need to use two buttons, which I have circled in red.
Say you want to colour a specific region light red, you click the tool that I marked B, and you'll see your cursor takes the shape of that tool. Then you left click the colour you want to use, i.e. the big circle. You'll notice that colour 1, which I marked C, changes to light red.
If you repeat this process but you RIGHT click a coloured circle instead of left clicking it, you will select the colour as colour 2. Let's click dark red. This way you can have both shades of red selected at the same time, which makes colouring in the map more convenient, especially when doing big countries.
Now you select the tool which I marked A. Let's get to colouring. Say you want to colour Indiana in light red and you want to colour Ohio in dark red. Easy. Left click Indiana and right click Ohio.

Maybe we can make a standardised OP with these instructions (and the template).
I think the use of the colours is pretty self explanatory, even though I always see people mess it up. But people can use the map how they want to, so I don't think we have to tell anyone how they should colour their map. The colours are more like suggestions. You don't have to use these colours, and you don't have to use all of them. When and how you use them is up to your interpretation only.

>>2402196
My father is married to a Burkinese woman who moved here 15y ago and is perfectly integrated. We visited her family in Ouagadougou 11y ago for a period of 3 weeks in July. We went to the city center a few times and also to some smaller suburbs. Also went swimming a few times and to a wildlife parc. The only paved roads I saw were in the center. The suburbs only had dirtroads and traffic rules are non existent. Most of our activities were staying inside and chatting with people though.

People are very nice over there, but you stand out alot as a white person. We were regularly swarmed by kids who wanted to touch our skin and shake hands.

During the day it's hot af and going outside during noon was hell for us. At night you had to watch out for mosquitos and sleep under a veil or a ventilator.

The best thing I remember was the food. Fresh fruit like mangos and baked bananas in a spicy sauce with some rice. The water strangely came in plastic bags instead of bottles and you had to bite open one of the edges before drinking.

>>2402870
Only in Brussels, which we all avoid like the plague
>>2402880
The Ardennes have some nice hiking trails if you're into that. I especially enjoyed the one that starts at the top of Signal de Botrange, the highest peak in Belgium. De Hoge Venen in general are nice, take a break in Spa if you find yourself nearby.
Antwerp has a nice historical centre and a massive shopping street if you're bringing a gf. A bicycle trip along the Damse Vaart from Bruges to Sluis is also nice if you want something sporty.
Tongeren has a Roman museum since there was a big settlement there in Roman times. Bastogne has a big war museum commemorating the Battle of the Bulge.
If you're in Ghent, go to the Vrijdagsmarkt on a thursday night if you want the full nightlife experience, it's where the locals frequent. Most of Ghent's massive student population parties in the Overpoort but it's highly overrated and smells like piss and vomit from a mile away, would not recommend unless you're into 18 year olds.
Bruges is mainly a tourist hotspot with not many locals unlike Ghent, which makes it feel a bit more artificial but still filled with beautiful medieval architecture, so still worth seeing.
Brussels is a shit city, don't visit.

What are the chances of there being 3 anons from the same small Belgian province in one thread? Crazy stuff.

I've been on that exact ship twice.

Cruises are by far the best way to do a vacation.
Pay a set price, about $1,000pp/pw often less.
That's it. It's all included. Drinks, food, alcohol, entertainment. It's all there and included.
You get to relax, eat some of the best food you will ever fucking have, and visit a new country every day.

The ships themselves are something else.
The Oasis class, which Wonder is part of, has literal fucking parks inside them.

I've been on 6 cruises total, and always had a good time.

If you ever wanted to go on one, do it.

Just don't cheap out and go with some jew cruise line.

Royal Caribbean, NCL, and Virgin are the best for the average person.
Celebrity, Viking, and Princess are nice but high-end. Like, you need to dress nice high-end.
Disney if you have kids.
Fuck any other cruise line. Especially Carnival.

>>2396394
I lived in Saigon for years. It's easy to get a job teaching but you have to have a teaching certificate and work permit. Be careful of shitty schools, make sure to ask around before you sign any binding contracts. The traffic is a lot worse now than it was a decade ago because there are cars everywhere and the roads aren't designed for it.
I consider it my second home and will love it until the day I die, but it takes a while to grow on you. It reveals its beauty over the course of months and years. It also has an immense amount of poverty, corruption, suffering, and like any big city it will swallow you and spit you out. The party culture has a dark side.
>>2396396
a lot of people say Hanoi is the New York and Saigon is the LA, Hanoi is cultural capital and Saigon is the business capital, and I think there's some truth to that.

Check out some of the facebook groups and ask around. Maybe save enough money to travel through VN for a month and stay in Saigon and Hanoi for a week or two before committing to a place.

The ESL market is glutted nowadays so it's a bit harder to find jobs in the big cities especially but you'll still be able to find something, especially during the summer when language centers are looking. During the school year it's common to teach during the day at a public school and nights/weekends at a language center.

I miss Vietnam.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2398801
If you think the Splash thing is about forced propaganda you're only partially right. It's being done as an example to the shareholders that the company is moving away from expensive maintenance and operating costs in favor of streamlined low cost and bare minimum crowd appeasement.
You see, a technocratic corporation such as Apple for example, would have little interest in continuing to invest large portions of the company's investments in the parks. So all the animatronics and original themed attractions will continue to be phased out in favor of reducing operating costs and making the Disney brand more valuable to the big buyer, which will definitely be a streaming giant since Disney+ is the company's main focus.
Obviously this also means that virtually nothing from the original Splash will remain. Imagine Frozen Ever After but longer since the layout is the only thing being recycled and that is exactly the attraction youre going to get. There will be a handful of actual animatronics but nothing like the previous amount. And they will mostly be projection mapped and screens will replace the physical sets.
Disney is essentially throwing the towel in to Universal as far as maintaining an equal or competitive quality for the attractions. Their assumption is that they can cut the costs of the parks to appease investors and still maintain the park attendance and money flow that comes from them.
And they are probably right. Look at your average Disney shill, even the casual ones. They will say everything was a worthy replacement regardless and continue to blow their savings each year taking their family because the brand is already engrained into their feeble brains and they will always be loyal no matter what.
In the eyes of the park enthusiasts Universal is about to become leaps and bounds ahead of Disney but that will never translate to fiscal consequence because the vast majority of money generated from Disney parks has nothing to do with these opinions.

That's why I wish people would stop extending the family category. Hagrid's is not a family coaster either. It's 50mph and has a 48" height requirement. The same height requirement as Millennium Force and Iron Gwazi. Hagrid's might be straddling categories but even RCDB lists it as 'thrill' (and Cheetah Hunt is listed as 'extreme', as it should be).

Tron is also listed on RCDB as thrill which is appropriate because it goes 60mph. But it's definitely below Hagrid's in intensity. It's basically a Tron-themed smooth RnRC without the inversions. A family coaster should top out at 40mph and have a height requirement around 38"-42". If Slinky Dog was 20mph faster with a 60mph launch it wouldn't be a family coaster.. it would also tear through the course and bunny hills and might actually be good

I think they took all the wrong conclusions of why Space Mountain is iconic. >>2401228

Ive never really seen the benefit to having a car if you are doing a fortnightly holiday in Orlando and only doing the theme parks.

Using me as an example, a UK/Ireland traveller going for 2 weeks to Orlando.
Car rental is about $600
Petrol is about $200 for the week
Parking Charges - dont even know how to price this. Used to be $25 a day at Disney which was an extra $300 alone

So lets call it an even $1000 for a couple / family to rent a car for 2 weeks.
Weve found that Ubers tend to work out at $50 a day - so basically $700 for the 2 weeks, and it means you can have a drink when you go out (not that drinking and driving has ever stopped yanks)

Personally, ive never seen an example where a car wins out vs internal transport and ubers unless you have a family of 8 and need a massive people carrier to get around Orlando.

I know America has a different perspective on driving, but for most tourists, a 20min wait here and there, and a 20min bus ride to a resot or theme park for free is often good enough

>>2401672
There are definitely different reasons why people won't go on different coasters. People will go on Space Mountain but not Expedition Everest because of how high up EE goes and how big they make the drop seem. Some people will go tall woodies but refuse to go on even the most mild inversion.

People definitely differ in both how easily they get the "lose your stomach" feeling and how much they tolerate it. Some people really hate the feeling, some people actively like it. some get it on even small log flumes, some need extremely fast/steep drops to feel it. I definitely feel it easily and dislike the feeling (but grin and bear it) , wish I knew how to lessen the feeling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401700
Inversions and heights are GP filters. If parks like Universal don’t mind the LSM electric bill, they don’t need lift hills and drops anyways which is more GP-friendly.

You should go on an S&S Screamin Swing 2-3x times in a row and you won’t get that stomach feeling anymore, not the same way anyways. It’s mostly psychological because you’re falling. On the swing you’ll get it the first time but on the backwards swing you probably won’t despite both being identical. Everybody is feeling something different and those who say they like it are not feeling the same uncomfortable feeling that you are. I used to get it as a teen and hated it and projected myself on others thinking somehow they liked it but they’re not feeling the same thing. I like drops and ejector airtime now and most of the time I feel nothing and wish I could feel something. Just don’t ever ride on an empty stomach and drink plenty of water.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401734

Its easier said than done.
But the only assistance I can offer is this

Take one of the more extreme thrill coasters you have access too and break it down into relative constituent parts.

>Height - 200m (so thats 10,200m below the cruising altitude of planes)
>Speed 50-70mph (you can drive faster than most coasters on the road
>Loops and Inversions (look at how long each element lasts for - probably less than 1 second before you are back on a nice banked curve or flat piece)
>Ride Time (probably less than 5mins all in including boarding, lift hill and the return to station - so its 5 mins out of your life that youll either enjoy or you wont)

Just look at the happy faces of people who come off the coaster.
Clearly they enjoy it. Its a safe ride.
Sure some people are rattled, and thrilled, and thats life

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2401509
Didn't really have any profound realizations, but traveling definitely helped me develop.

I've been using /trv/ since about 2012 and took my first-ever overseas trip in 2013. I was, at the time, a reasonably attractive but incredibly awkward, borderline autistic sperg. I had no social confidence, was intimidated by women, and could barely hold a conversation with other men. Looking back, I don't think I had any hobbies outside of reading books and playing video games. I was, overall, a very boring, sterile person.

Everything started changing after my first trip, which took me to:
>Turkey
>Greece
>Iraq
>Georgia
>Armenia
>the UAE
>India
>Kazakhstan

Since I often had to interact with people in completely different languages, I quickly shed my fear of social rejection. I also drank for the first time, had my first few hook-ups, and got involved in what turned out to be a very, very bad long-distance relationship.

I kept traveling after that and have been to somewhere between 50-60 countries. Traveling exposed me to a lot of new interests: I learned to speak two languages--Hindi to fluency, and Turkish to the B2 level--started riding motorcycles, and came up with a dissertation topic for my doctorate.

No idea how I'd have turned out if I wasn't a /trv/tard, but I'm pretty happy with my present life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Traveling helped me develop a life philosophy based around the fact that life sucks everywhere as much as it can be good.
Living anywhere will always have pluses and minuses and the sum of both will, as a rule, tend towards zero. It's all up to how you subjectively weight these factors.
I've lived in and interacted with people, both locals and expats in many places from 1st to 3rd world and everywhere follows the same rule. Numbers such as GDP per capita or HDI do play a role in how "livable" a place is, but there's plenty of invisible things, including culture, language, mentality that will make or break it for one person or the other.
Living abroad is exaggeratedly romanticised as much as sticking to your home country due to some misplaced patriotism is. I have grown to live without attachments to a particular place, just being able to objectively embrace and enjoy/suffer all the highs and lows each particular place has to offer.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2402209
You pretty much described Nice and the surrounding area (Cannes, Antibes etc, basically the French Riviera and the "arrière-pays niçois").
Not the cheapest area of France, possibly one of the most expensive ones but nowhere as crazy as Paris, especially if you're not after some nice house with a view over the sea.
It has mountains within 20 minutes of driving, and 1.5-2 hours takes you to ski stations and national parks (and there are buses taking you there).
It's right next to Northern Italy, the climate is absolutely great most of the year.
There's nice architecture in the area, more job opportunities than in many areas of France, population is quite young as young people from all over France come work here.
Yes, it can get expensive, but it's still cheaper than Paris and it's still ok to live there if you don't get too close to the sea. The further you are from the sea, the cheaper it is.

>>2402209
You might consider Toulouse as well. It's the fourth largest city in the country (after Paris, Lyon, and Marseille). It's what passes for a tech hub in France, with AirBus and some startups around to provide jobs. It's a university town, so it has a very active nightlife. The bars around the Place Saint-Pierre are always PACKED, especially Chez Tonton (even on weekdays). Le Saint des Seins is also worth checking out, though that one only gets busy on weekends.

Rents are cheap, the climate is very good since the city is so far south. The only downside I can think of is the fact that it's so far inland. But there's lakes and shit you can do a day trip to in the summer.

Unfortunately, there's many blacks, but that can't be helped these days when it comes to France. It didn't seem as bad as other cities, though.

Pic related, a summer night along the Garonne

>>2402477
They have a fair amount of tourism, but it didn't strike me as an expat city in particular. Most of those types go off to Madrid, being the capital, or Barcelona. IIRC the houses are more affordable too. It still has some edgy shit like crappy 'ANTIFA ZONE' graffiti, but in reality most people are extremely chill. Never had any crime issues or felt unsafe. There's stuff open until very late in the night. Even very late I'd sometimes see families. It's a beautiful city, but much like the rest of Spain it very ugly modern civil architecture (France and Italy have their share too, but Spain is arguably dogshit when it comes to this). There's lots of smaller towns nearby which are cosy for a visit or possibly work out as a home too. Sagunto in particular. Albaraccin is one of the best places for bouldering in the world, and it is close by. The metro is cheap and covers pretty much covers most of the city. Maybe rent an Airbnb for a month and see how you find it? Then check out different suburbs, etc. I rented a small studio flat in the city center for 540 + bills, and split it with my ex. So we ended up paying each like 300€ per month.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2402732
There's places like this. A lot of mountain towns are like this, often for purely business reasons, a lot of chains like Panda Express will only locate stores within so many minutes drive off a truck route from a distribution center so it can be restocked efficiently.

Difficult to access places have few chains. I live in a town in that has no city government and few regulations but very few chains (a bank and a regional supermarket) and most businesses here, even the utility companies, only exist here. I think its not viable for big corps because the population density is too low and it takes too long to get stuff in and out and the roads can close and everyone knows each other and prefers it that way.

There's upsides and downsides. It's more expensive, getting certain things requires at least a 30 drive each way and you get tired of the same food all the time which here the food options are American, Italian-American and Mexican-American and that's it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2400963
>what do you do to prevent crime when traveling?
Not much, I just exercise common-sense levels of caution. I have used hotel safes and left wallets/documents locked up in them when in a few places with bad reputations for pickpocketing or street crime, just going out with a bit of cash in a shirt pocket, but I have never been robbed and never bothered to resort to things like decoy wallets or secretive money belts, although I know many who have and respect their paranoia.
>is there a camera you can buy and set up to point at your stuff when you leave it?
I’m sure there are many such things, but I don’t know that I see much reason to bother.

>how do you keep it locked up safe?
Again, I’ve used hotel safes before. I’ve also got locking suitcases, but I don’t know if I have ever actually locked them. I don’t know if it makes much difference, or any difference at all, but I don’t usually stay in cheap places.

>>2399005
The list of vaccines you probably need to be prudent goes down if you're staying in cities. Assuming you got your childhood vaccinations (MMR, DTaP, Polio), the most important are Hep A/B and Typhoid. You should get Tetanus booster as well unless you had a booster within the last 10 years (you probably had one at 12 years old). If you're going to Cambodia, also consider Cholera vaccination, which is a drinkable vaccine and gives some protection against food poisoning too.
If you plan on spending time in the countryside, you should get Japanese Encephalitis and strongly consider getting 3 shot Rabies PREP. (You'll still need to get any risky animal encounters treated but getting the 3 shots in advance will stop your trip from being ruined and might save your life if you don't get any further treatment.) These shots are really expensive in Western countries but they're cheap if you get them in SEA.
And rather than taking advice from randoms on the Internet, you should visit a travel medicine doctor. They'll try to sell you on a lot more vaccines than you probably need, but they'll rank their importance depending on your destinations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2399245
>How is it with cash? Is it necessary or can you function with just a card?
You can do almost everything with a card. Mid-sized and bigger restaurants will take it, use booking sites to do all your hotel reservations, convenience and grocery stores will do Apple Pay, Grab and Food Panda can use a card, etc. (Grab can be picky with your card - it will need to be one that can do security authorization PINs.) You'll need cash for street and cheap restaurants, most bars, night markets, prozzies, etc.
>Any services to specifically take/avoid? (especially getting from the airport to hotel, how do I not get scammed/overcharged?)
Fly in BKK and take the metro in the basement of the airport directly into the city. You'll probably take it to Phaya Thai, where you walk through a connecting tunnel to connect to the BTS. Make sure your hotel is near a BTS or MTS station.
Don't use taxis. They've gotten better in recent years but you'll always have less problems sticking with Grab.
Whenever someone tries to sell you something, say "my krop". The "my" part means "no" and "krop" is a respectful word that makes anything polite. (Women say "ka" - don't imitate female Thai or you'll be a joke.) Adding "krop" takes the edge off anything you say, and even a drunken Thai looking to start something will probably look elsewhere
>Are there any cooming forums? I have read bits here, but would like to read up on experiences and places more so I know what im getting into.
I forget their names. Just google.
>Can I find a reasonably priced hotel with a gym/pool or are those only the upper tier ones?
Easier to find hotels with pools than gyms, and the gyms are usually shit. If you're lucky, there will be some machines that max out low. Look for 4 star hotels.
>How is tinder/other apps in there? Do the girls speak english enough to hold a convo?
Thailand is life on easy mode. Pay for Tinder Gold, set your profile to Bangkok and just wait for the matches to roll in.

The cost of living difference between Cambodia, Vietnam, and Thailand comes down to a few dollars per day. (This can vary between cities but is mostly true for the countryside.) There are big differences when you go really cheap (bare bones survival is cheapest in Cambodia) or still want some luxuries (standard of living rises fastest in Thailand compared to additional costs).
It would be better for you to give what you want your daily or monthly budget to be, and some of us can probably tell you what you can expect in different countries at that level.
If you have "a few thousand" ($3000?) and want to get away for "a few months" (3 months?) then you can live quite well anywhere in the region on $1000/month as long as you get out of the tourist/expat ghettos.

>>2401364
It's hard to tell someone who wants to stretch their money how far they can stretch it in SEA. If you've never been in a developing country before (or even if you have), you might be the type of person who wants to stay in a comfortable bubble - restaurants with English menus, hotels with air conditioning and hot water close to restaurants/bars, taking taxis/Grab instead of figuring out local buses, etc. If you use mid-range hostels or the cheapest hotels, order Food Panda and local restaurants for most of your meals, and limit drinking alcohol is bars and restaurants, you can get by with a budget of $20-30/day (half of that on rent), depending where you are. This doesn't include travel costs to move around.
The best way to bring that down further is to find a long term place to stay. You're probably not going to want to sign a lease, so the low-hanging fruit is to look for share houses and rooms on Facebook and maybe local expat forums, depending on the country. Realistically, expect to pay about $200/month for something simple and shared. You can certainly get cheaper but the really cheap places aren't advertised by other expats or on FB.
Food can get brought down if you cook your own food, or if you learn to eat where locals eat. Think $1/meal. Add in extra expenses and you can skint your way down to $500/month budget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401510
Now the next problem is your visa costs. Looking at Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam, all of these countries technically only allow 30 days upon entry. (I think Thailand is currently 45.) Thailand has free entry for most passports, Cambodia is $36, Vietnam is $25. Taking a bus between these countries is currently $25-35 one way.
In Thailand, you can extend your visa-free entry by another 30 days for $55 without leaving the country. In Cambodia you can extend another 30 days for about $35 without leaving the country. You can't currently extend in Vietnam. You can leave and re-enter Thailand twice by land borders every calendar year, unlimited times by air, but there's always the chance that Thai immigration will turn you back. One way to lessen this is to pay for a 60 day single entry visa (which can also be extended for 30 days without leaving the country) or a 180 day ME visa (which has more application requirements and a big cost). You can do visa runs with Cambodia and Vietnam indefinitely - they don't care.
So on the surface it will seem you can spend the most time in Thailand without doing expensive border runs, but Thailand is the country that's harder to live skint. Their whole economy is designed to suck money from farang, and even in remote areas you'll find yourself getting gouged and being resented if you barter too hard. There are places you can still do it (Chiang Mai and Chiang Rai are very budget and backpacker friendly, along with almost all the north). And if you get a Thai gf, which will be inevitable unless your tastes lean towards men or katoey, she will show you how to make your money go further.
Cambodia and Vietnam are easier to live on a budget, in my opinion, for various reasons. Don't expect as smooth an experience getting to different parts of them by local transport. But you can live in hotels in Siem Reap or Hoi An, eat meals in restaurants with English menus, and drink $0.5-1.00 beers in bars on about $20/day.

>Is sildenafil causing hearing loss a real risk?
Interesting thread to bring this up in. There is no conclusive research, but there is a strong correlation between older men who use sildenafil being twice as likely as men the same age to show some hearing loss. There's a theory that the same mechanism of sildenafil that makes blood flow easier could also affect the longevity of ear hair follicles that are used for hearing. Using a high dose of sildenafil daily would put a similar strain on your hearing as working in a loud environment. But this is just a theory because it doesn't seem to affect all men the same way. There might be a genetic factor because, for whatever reason, it seems to happen more to men in the US population than in the UK and Europe.
A sudden onset of loss of hearing after using sildenafil is rare, usually affects one ear, and appears within 24 hours. It's a rare side effect - about as common as getting priapism from sildenafil. It's thought to be reversible if you get medical attention soon enough. Treatment involves high doses of Medrol for a week to bring down inflammation in the affected ear.

Lived in Boston during my college years, can confirm. It's also the worst "major" city if you're looking for excitement as a young man. Nightlife? Forget about it. Last call's at 1:30am, the subway closes before that (even on weekends). If you can even afford a car within city limits, parking is exorbitantly priced and hard to find. Expect to pay $44 to keep your car in a garage for a sit-down dinner and still have to Uber to the restaurant. It's not even legal to do happy hour.

However, the dating scene is very good; in a city of 600k people, at least 50k will be coed women at the most expensive schools in all America. That's not even counting the master's students and knowledge workers drawn to the city. Including pic related. The city attracts high-quality young poon from all over the world, though of course it can't compare to cities like New York or London.

In fact, Boston is not really a city at all. It's more of a glorified large town. It's the 24th largest city in the country, even fucking Indianapolis is bigger. It rises to 11th when you take into account all the suburbs in the surrounding area, where there's nothing to do. Boston is not as large as you'd think for a city with its cultural and economic capital. It punches far above its weight in terms of the food scene and other cultural attractions. But once you've been there a year or two, you'll have seen it all. You won't constantly be discovering new things like you could in a real city like New York.

There's nothing to do apart from work, pay overpriced rents/mortgages, buy expensive things, and raise a few kids in a city that's decently safe by American standards. The employment and educational opportunities are world-leading, but they're all the place has going for it. It's an open-air bagne for the upper middle class.

Itaewon is dead, don't go. The crowd crush made it so nobody goes there. Hongdae has better bars and clubs. Itaewon is mostly longues--great with friends, but boring if you wanna go and party, meet random people, and your typical nightlife experience. There's also a lot more clubs and bars in Hongdae, much more compact too. There's a main drag in Itaewon that parallels the main road, which is where >90% of the action is vs Hongdae which is multiple roads packed full of clubs, bars, norebangs, food, whatever. Just full of a ton of stuff. Itaewon is more expensive and has stricter dress codes, which is likely due to Hongdae mostly being very young college kids.

Mike's Cabin is mandatory for all foreigners to visit. They play latin music, but its very foreigner friendly, great drinks, cheap, big, and because it's so foreigner friendly all the Koreans there are going to be more receptive to you. From there you have other options depending on what music you like. Aura and Cocoon, which play electronic music--unless you go the Aura Bar which is connected but separate from Aura. NB2 and Sinkhole are hiphop clubs.

I highly recommend you club hop. Do not stay at just one place. You could literally go to, and I have, all the clubs I previously mentioned in the same night and have a fantastic time, Clubs pick up after 10 pm, peak at around ~1-2 AM, drop off at around 3-4am, and die completely by 5 am unless you go to a place like Madholic. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386906
Rural Colombia is indeed gorgeous in many spots, and Costa Rica has some of the most beautiful concentrated nature I’ve ever seen anywhere, while being safer and easier to get around (although Colombia is mostly safer than its reputation nowadays too). Urban Colombia, however, despite a bit of grit and risk in some spots, is far more charming than urban Costa Rica—San Jose, through which you will have to pass, is an ugly shithole, and while nearly every other town in the country is somewhat more attractive they’re small and have limited historical or cultural interest, apart from Cartago, which has an OK little colonial center.

All that said, the food isn’t particularly good in either country IMO. There are a few local specialties that are worth eating once or twice, but I would say that both Colombian and Costa Rican cooking tend toward the heavy, greasy, and bland.

Mexico or especially Thailand are both far better places to eat as far as I’m concerned. I don’t know Puerto Vallarta specifically, but Mexican beaches I have visited in the Yucatán and Riviera Maya can be very nice if a bit resort/package tourism dominated.

I know Thailand very well—lived there for years—and will always love the place, but I encourage most people to go somewhere other than Bangkok first and see BKK on the way out. I love the place in a lot of ways but love almost everywhere else in the country more. It’s hot, smoggy, has miserable traffic, and isn’t especially attractive, so it can make a bad first impression, but it undeniably has a great deal going on. There are as many favorite beaches there as there are people, but I’ve had great times on Ko Samui (easy mode, avoid Chaweng Beach, which is sleazy and grubby); Phuket (even easier mode, avoid Patong Beach, which is sleazy and grubby and Russian Mafia, I like the southern tip of the island); Ko Chang (no airport so takes a bit longer to reach, mix of hippies and smaller resorts); and others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389185
The best way is to just not do it. Tell your GP before you go on the trip that you're going on a trip, and you need your prescription for the entire duration of the trip. Add one month or something (depends on the lenght of your trip) to make sure that even if you get delayed for whatever reason you're not left without your presciption.
There are ofc variables, like the majority of the world has cheaper meds than the USA. And also some meds are extremely illegal in some countries, so look it all up. Based on the main ingredient, not the brand name.
In some third world countries your solution might work great, and you might get what you need, for cheaper, too. But let's say you go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to. The only reason to bring your home prescription is in case customs wants to check why you have certain meds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389484
I actually agree with all of your advice here, but
> go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to.

Isn’t necessarily true in my experience. A lot of European cities have walk-in travel clinics for foreigners that can sometimes fill prescriptions for visitors based on a foreign script, with relatively few questions asked. My wife accidentally ran out of thyroid meds while on holiday in Portugal once and was able to get what she needed from a clinic just by showing them the empty box with her name on the prescription label. And when I moved countries, I was able to get an armload of prescriptions from my new GP just by telling him the medications I needed (I have multiple chronic health conditions). That last case is different, of course, because it was implicit that I would have some kind of ongoing relationship with the doctor and he would eventually see blood work for me.

But assuming the medications involved aren’t dangerous or tightly controlled (probably wouldn’t work for anything psychoactive, definitely wouldn’t work for narcotics), it is often possible to get an emergency script from a foreign doctor in the west.

Still agree that the best option is to get a “vacation fill” of whatever you’re on to last as long as you will be away whenever possible, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I hate flying, going to be flying in a month from california to london, what's a drug that's guaranteed to knock me out cold the whole time? I'm awake at night a month ahead thinking about this flight, it's driving me crazy with anxiety. I want to try a few different medications before i go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391230
Ambien or another high-test hypnotic sleeping pill might do the trick. If you’re not concerned about potential abuse and addiction, you might also talk to a doctor about a small quantity of an anxiolytic like Xanax or Ativan, but any drug in the barbiturate or benzodiazepine families is more serious business than people like to think, and shouldn’t be used too casually. They’re all physically habit-forming with nasty withdrawal symptoms, and some people get unpleasant benzo hangovers that can leave you groggy and stupid for an extended period. They can, however, ameliorate anxiety symptoms very effectively in the short term, even if they don’t necessarily render you unconscious.

You should also think about jet lag—I agree with those experts who say that you should avoid trying to sleep at times when you wouldn’t be asleep at your destination while in transit. But it’s virtually impossible to do this perfectly, so if you need to conk out to survive a flight it’s not the end of the world even if it’s suboptimal.

If they haven’t already by the time I finish typing this, someone will surely suggest combining alcohol with one or more of the above. It might work, but I think it’s à fundamentally dumb idea—while alcohol can be good for making you pass out, it’s terrible for sleep quality, so it will make you less likely to stay asleep, and you’re likely to wake up unrested with a hangover in the middle of your flight.

I recommend looking up some anti-anxiety breathing exercises and guided meditation—it may sound like bullshit but in my experience as an anxious person it can also actually work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
I appreciate the help, i want some hardcore shit, i have all these thoughts of dying already and its a month till my flight, idk i never take any medication or pills of any kind, but im close to cancelling my flight out of fear and i need the assurance i can get something that will make me knock out for 10 hours. I appreciate the advice, i need to go see a doctor ASAP

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
Oh, and if you do end up going with a sleeping pill like Ambien or Lunesta, try it at home a few days before you fly to see how long it lasts in your case, so you can time your dosing appropriately. You will not enjoy dragging your ass through customs and immigration while still deeply under the influence of one of these drugs, nor do you want to still be comatose when you land.

Another psychoactive medication you might want to discuss with your doctor is trazodone; it’s an ancient antidepressant, but it also has some anti-anxiety and sedative properties and used to get prescribed for insomnia. I use a small dose daily at bedtime as part of a depression and anxiety regimen, and while I can’t say it knocks me out for ten hours, it does make me sleepy and I wake up more relaxed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391732
>Any tips on motion sickness pills? Never had them
Many of the OTC ones are based on dimenhydrinate; seems to work OK for my kids. Can make you a bit sleepy but not enough to be used as a sedative. It’s a dissociative/quasi-hallucinogen in the case of massive overdose or deliberate abuse by bored teenagers. Don’t drink alcohol while taking it, less for side effects and more because it seems to stop it from working almost completely.

You can also get scopolamine pills or patches, although these may be script-only depending on where you live; my uncle, who liked deep sea fishing but could also barf walking through a puddle, depended on these.

Another Rx-only drug that in my limited experience might be the most powerful is Ondansetron, AKA Zofran, which can even keep chemotherapy patients from upchucking. My wife got it once in the ER when she had debilitating nausea and she stopped throwing up in seconds, although she had it as an injection rather than a tablet. Not sure if it’s given often for self-administration.

Copper-alloy wristbands and similar talismans work only if you are highly responsive to placebo effects.

I’ve been doing it since I was a kid, and my dad has been doing it since the 60s. I guess it’s more of an education thing. I just want to try and see more things. When you’re abroad, at least for me, you become like a toddler. Everything is brand new and you need to learn quick to adapt, whether it’s a few words in a new languages or new cultural norms to get used to. And finally, learn about a lot of things, such as local history, geographical data, wildlife (I do birdwatching and there are species of birds you can never see in other places). Why just look at pictures in the book I have read instead of actually going there?
Learning is life’s greatest pleasure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2399138
I get a lift from being in new and unfamiliar environments. I also like landscapes/cityscapes, museums, concerts, and historical sites, but even just sitting at a coffeeshop in a place I don’t know is inherently exciting to me. I also get a weird kick out of buying completely mundane things like toothpaste and deodorant. Banal everyday life places and things that are recognizable but not the same are genuinely entertaining for me.

I also like listening to local languages and trying to pick some up, and I like to try unfamiliar food, although I’m not a “foodie” or glutton.

My brother, on the other hand, finds travel inherently uncomfortable, and would generally rather stay home. He will travel to visit me and my family, or to see friends once in a while, and he has fun, but it’s not something he would choose for fun if someone else weren’t making him do it. Different strokes.

>>2401113
Spend a few nights in ryokan for a Japanese feel, some have outdoor hotsprings, some have private ones.

Spend the rest in a hostel to meet people because you are alone, then go together to arcades, purikuri, kaiten sushi, curry bar, ramen bar, and izakaya. Try some specialty cafes. Check out Harajuku and Akihabara for interesting neighborhoods. Besides that if you like museums, shrines, parks, find them. If you go outside Tokyo go to Osaka and Kyoto. If you want to do less ventured places let me know.

Is your flight includes and from where? Long flights in economy are painful, I would say cut your flights in half and upgraded to business.

posts.com:
I live in North Seattle and work downtown. You're gonna be in shelton? Okay, here goes.

>explore nightlife
Not in fucking shelton lol. Seattle is really your best bet, but even that has a bunch of queer attractions. I say you should go around Ballard for your walks, as most of Seattle is pretty grey and littered with hobos.
>enjoy snow/general cold atmosphere
Go to the olympics or the cascades, you'll like it a lot. Just make sure you have the right type of transport though. I would say the olympics since you're closer to them, and traffic can be a bitch on the east side.
>hook up on dating apps
Again you aren't doing this in shelton lmfao. You can try seattle but the only girls you'll get are weird alt girls with severe mental illness or white/asian girls with sky-high standards living off daddy's microsoft/boeing/amazon money.

>frozen road
This doesn't happen much, and it's particularly rare on the peninsula where it rains constantly. Don't worry about this, I can count the number of days per year where shit actually freezes up.
>hard precipitation, to the point events are cancelled or no one shows
Shit does not get cancelled for rain outside of tsunamis. If you're there in the summer, it's actually quite dry. July and August in particular are almost completely devoid of rain.
>general shitty weather to the point I can't go anywhere
Again, super unlikely that this happens as torrential rain is very rare outside the pacific coast. Anything more than a moderate drizzle in Seattle's wet months is also quite uncommon. We're built for the fucking rain.

Next post will be about my insider knowledge about what to actually do.

Want to go see the new Kimetsu movie? That's gonna be a lottery to win tickets for a showing in a month from now. Want to go to a concert? Lottery two months in advance. Expo/Sporting event? You guessed it, lottery. You want to get into a bar? Lottery at the door. Hungry for a bite to eat? Lottery to get a reservation. Need to take a shit? Hope you can win the toilet lottery or you're gonna be crapping your pants.
Japan is a country of lotteries and you should only go if you consider yourself a lucky person and are willing to plan months in advance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401336
The Japanese ice cream company Akagi Nyuguyo raised the price of their beloved Garigari-kun cones in 2016. You've probably seen the light blue ice creams in anime or other japanese media. In any case, tehy issued an apology video announcig the hike of 10JPY
Yes, 10JPY or at the time 0,09USD warranted an official apology
The average Japan is far more cheaper than a Canadian. Canadians are just fine paying high taxes while the average Jap will pinch every penny he can.
The whole country lives on strong welfare mentality without the welfare. They've had to struggle har since the economic miracle ran out in the 80s

Jokes aside it is and it isn't. Public transport is cheap and you can get most popular fast foods such as ramen, takoyaki etc. extremely cheap compared to the West. I'll use my cunt of Finland as a reference: The average bowl of ramen here (2 slices of pork, 1 egg, some corn, some edamame, seaweed, noodles and stock) goes for 15,50€ with no optional extras. In Japan you could get that for 1000 yen or around 7€ and then you could pick extra eggs, noodles, pork, you name it for 100-300 yen per item. At the ramen restaurant that sell 15€ bowls 4 takoyaki balls costs 7€ and for that in Japan you'd get double, if not triple.
Then again sushi is around the same if not even more expensive in Japan, but the size of the fish slice they give you there justifies the high price. Beer in Japan cost me 450-500yen at a restaurant or 3€ and for that you'd get a pint size can at a supermarket in Finland. Restaurant beer is around 8€ here
It's all relative and as everything some things are cheaper, some are more expensive. If your currency stays strong and the yen dips during your trip there then you win, if by whatever miracle the yen gets a small boost you meh, it's still a little bit cheaper there

https://www.babymetal.com/babymetal-begins/
If you scroll down, you'll see a bunch of options. The first two are for fan club (THE ONE'S ARK) which I doubt apply to you, one for Japanese residents and they just recently added one for Gaijins. After that is Clear Code, and then ones after it say "後日発表" which means they'll be announced later. First one is the official advance lottery for Japanese, the second one is the advance lottery for Gaijin, the third one is for Play Guide which is a Japanese ticket sale site, then an Amuse+ option, and the VERY bottom is for General Sales (no lottery, you just race to buy the tickets before they sell out) if any tickets are still left.

A lot of Japanese food is just simmered in one pot, so diahes like nikujaga, umani, chikuzen-ni, and sukiyaki are easy enough to whip up at home with whatever ingredients you like. Miso soup has plenty of variations as well. If you're in the mood for something more junky, yakisoba hits the spot. Curry/hayashi rice/cream stew/beef stew are all pretty common in Japanese households. The sky's the limit, really.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401548
I went from Hongu in the kii peninsula, to sendai in one day. Was a a dcent bit more travel than 7 hours, like 11 or something.
I was in japan for like 33 days overall though, so 'losing' a day wasn't so bad.
And hell the first hour was an amazing bus ride through the mountains, then 3 hours on a scenic train along the coast to Nagoya.
Rest was bullet trains which works out to 7 hours, so same as yours. Even that part wasnt too bad, just make sure you get a seated ticket in advance. I was sitting on the floor in between carriages from Nagoya to Tokyo, no seats left.
Bullet trains are comfy and have plenty of room to get up and stroll about. Proper toilets, smoking rooms, snack trolley (if you forgot to bring enough). Combined with seeing so much of the country, really a full day of bullet train travel is enjoyable in itself.

Where are you going from and to, and why in one day? If it makes sense for your plans then it isn't necessarily a bad idea.
Plus if theres the option you may even be able to start the 7 hour journey pretty late afternoon and still get where you need to. So that really you'd only be missing a single evening.
You could also consider an overnight bus as an alternative, giving you the day 'before' and 'after' in each location a full day, rather than eating into either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Been here about 30 days now. The "honeymoon" phase or the romanticism is starting to wear off. It has been accelerated though in my opinion. A lot of its my own fault for not thoroughly planning, but even then there would still be a lot of unanswered questions since im not doing the standard tourism.

For the average person its pretty easy to come for 1-3 weeks, do minimal planning and leave almost never experiencing any of the minutia. Im doing close to 90 days and that alone puts you in the 30+ day prescription territory if you take any. Its just enough time that you might start considering longer term stuff as well like a shared house, local phone number, gym membership etc. You quickly start to figure out that unless you have a temporary resident card or some type of sponsor that things get complicated fast. The longer you are here the more you start to see that things are a bit of a facade. Didn't know much about Japan before I came here other than the normal platitudes "quirky, good food, nice people, drones, high trust" etc.

A lot of the people here a pretty normal, the food is a shit ton of carbs and almost no protein, have met a ton of nice people but I have also run into people that are passive aggressive, rude, or do coward shit. Have had better interactions with Bosozoku then some random people kek. Also the high trust thing is a myth. Yeah you can leave your laptop on a table, but dont chance it. Bicycles and umbrellas get stolen here all the time. Also not sure what the cops do here. In the U.S. cops get called pretty quick for a lot of things. Not sure. I know Red Shoes bar and pub in Tokyo was historically famous as a hangout spot for the biggest Japanese rock bands back in the 1980s.

>Red Shoes has a long history. It first opened on the corner of a street in the still quiet Nishi-Azabu on the 5th of December, 1981. It quickly became the hot spot among the cultural front liners of the time, gathering together artists from many fields.A fierce red room with a big drawing of “Raijin・Fujin” on the wall, Red Shoes was a place for good drinks and authentic Chinese cuisine. Movies & music videos played on the screen endlessly, while rock music played in the background. Or, if you wanted to listen to something special, you could request your favorite songs from the rock’n’roll jukebox by the entrance.

>The odd combination of “Raijin・Fujin”, the drinks, and the Chinese food created a unique atmosphere, but it was Red Shoes’s connection to the music that drew the musicians in, not just from Japan but from all over the world. At times, it was the place to party at the end of a gig, at other times it was the place musicians went to when they wanted to drink ‘til dawn with their friends. Many big names from overseas, such as the The Rolling Stones, David Bowie, Todd Rundgren, Japan, Bryan Ferry, David Byrne etc. enjoyed their private time at Red Shoes.

posts.com:
>>2401698
I have made a trip to Nagano for like a week and I'm probably going to Osaka for 2 weeks. If you are doing 90 days and don't have a huge itinerary and don't mind a little discomfort then you can do some different transportation arrangements. For example I took the Shinkansen to Nagano to see the snow monkeys, snowboard, and go to Kusatsu Onsen. You can do all that via bus for pretty cheap. Way faster on the Shinkansen but there's other logistics. Like the Shinkansen takes you to Nagano but then you need another 1 hour bus ride to get to Kusatsu which is a direct bus route from Tokyo. For 80-90 days you aren't exactly speed running. You can stay in Airbnbs on the outskirts of town and take a 45 minute train ride to do stuff for the day. 2 hours is a lot for someone that's only staying a week or two. Also know that with your tourist visa you can only do very basic stuff. Trying to rent anything or use certain services etc is likely very difficult if not impossible. You can basically do all the basic stuff a tourist can. Also translate is usually only one way. If you have translate on your phone you can ask questions and gesture but people usually don't have a way to translate back. Maybe get a Japanese keyboard or something. Best to just avoid complex questions or older people kek. Also travel light. I know you are going to be here for 3 months but try and stick to maybe just a backpack or backpack + suitcase max. You can get almost everything you need at donki.

I don't know exactly what travel options you have. ie, JR pass, how much you want to spend etc.
But from the quick google maps I just did, its like 5.15 hours (izumo to nara) and 6 hours (ise to nikko).
Both even giving options to leave at around 6pm (arriving at 11.30-12 at night depending). Meaning you don't really miss any days at all.
I personally wouldn't hesitate to do this if it made my itinerary flow easy or made accommodation easier/cheaper (more consecutive nights in less places, rather than more moving and checking in/out).
Splitting it up would be based on whether you are just stopping in that place because you think its easier (probably wont be with extra check in check out), or if you actually want to see that place and it doesn't interrupt other plans/schedule.

Also give a look at the sunrise izumo train, i believe thats included in JR pass for the cheapest seats and may be the best way to go from Izumo to Osaka (then figure out the nara part separate), but im not sure on its timetable or anything so no promises its that helpful.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2402055
You can (or at least should) be able to bring them in your carry on. They can't be in checked baggage because if they were to suddenly ignite in the cargo hold of the aircraft it could cause serious damage to the plane. If you are checking your bag, then straight up just carry it onto the flight in your pocket.

I'm a big fan of Sumo, I haven't been to a tournament in person yet, but I'm going in May!
Sumo starts in the morning and ends about 6pm. The early bouts are the bottom divisions and there's usually only a few people in the audience - it's probably not worth watching. Higher divisions start about 2pm.
If you haven't seen sumo before you might want to try and watch some matches and learn about some of the wrestlers for the best experience.
Time between bouts can be 5 minutes of watching the wrestlers doing the pre-bout routine, and it can be boring.

Just how autistic are you guys because there are foreigners who live action roleplay as medieval knights in Japan.

For example, Vail Visconti is one of the main SCA officers in Japan and his titles are Count Baron from the Stronghold of Vale de Draco and The Palatine Barony of the Far West. The SCA stands for The Society for Creative Anachronism, an international living history group with the aim of studying and recreating mainly Medieval European cultures and their histories before the 17th century. Founded in 1966, the non-profit educational corporation has over 30,000 paid members as of 2017 with about 60,000 total participants in the society (including members and non-member participants).

Most Japanese SCA members have joined this medieval martial arts organization called Castle Tintagel in order to learn how to fight while wearing European medieval armor and some members include even employees from Monolith Soft, Sega, and Type Moon.

>>2402808
If you can't turn or stop, the last place you want to be is a resort. Find a local mountain that barely even has a triple lift and avoid cat tracks. I can get through blacks pretty easily and still prefer some local mountains in the states since they have fun terrain parks. Big resorts are money pits and attract a lot of beginners. There's a big difference between 20 beginners at a local mountain and 5-700 at a resort. There usually aren't long lift lines at local mountains too. Seen 1 hour lift lines at some bigger resorts.

Hill ratings are different everywhere. You were probably on a blue. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402853
Usually there's a trail map at the top of the chair lift or somewhere closer to the base. Sometimes you can even get a free paper one. It will show what route to take for greens, blues, black and terrain parks usually in orange. Generally anyone can do greens, blues are a little steeper and sometimes have mogul runs which are like hundreds of booba close together in the middle of the run and if you don't know how to do them it can suck pretty bad. Most mountains are green and blue heavy with only a few black runs and the blacks usually have a chair lift that's hard to get to or goes to the very top. They usually put warning signs on the blacks which say "no begginer skiers beyond this point"

It's all pretty easy to figure out. Also cat track routes are green and they typically don't go I'm a straight line and curve around the map. If you are on a snowboard, try and avoid these if you can. Lots of flat spots and if you brake it can mean you are going to have to clip out and walk a bit. Stick with greens until you can easily switch between toeside and healside or if skiing then very little pizza and no extremely wide turns. Once you get to blues start going fast and mess around with terrain parks, moguls, and open tree runs. Also if you didn't already know, the person in front of you lower on the hill has the right of way, always yield to them as it's the law

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401815
>How seriously do airlines take their 7kg limit in this area?
Some don't bother to weigh hand luggage, some do but give you leeway within a 1-2kg of the limit, and some will try to make you check your bag or pay an extra fee if you're 0.2kg over.
>If they complain about me carrying more, could I just take out my jacket and put on 2 sweaters?
Preempt this by doing it before you approach the counter. Use a light jacket with big pockets and load them with your heaviest things. Your bag and 7kg of clothes is a lot of clothing, so your excess weight is probably electronics, toiletries, etc. Keep your heaviest stuff on your body.
>Do you have experience with traveling with only one bag?
Yes, for short trips (under 3 months) when I plan to move around a lot, it's the best way to travel.

I was there last month, may have been one of the people on the other thread you mentioned. Definitely would recommend Baalbek and Jeita Grotto. Heard good things about Byblos while there too, but didn't make it there. Like you said everything is close so you can probably do day trips for everything.

For money make sure to bring all the money you will need for the trip into the country in USD and then exchange for the local currency once you arrive.

It isn't so bad as others said here, at least for tourists in my opinion, but I also didn't see the country as it was 10 years ago, which was almost certainly better. You can go and have a good time for sure. One advantage of the current situation is there isn't as many tourists so if you go somewhere like Baalbek for example it won't be full of people.

You can get around pretty inexpensively with their bus system. Can look up how to navigate it if you need. Uber is good, at least around Beirut, but make sure to change your option to Cash on it, else your trip will be hundred of dollars due to exchange.

I felt pretty safe everywhere I went, worst thing that happened was maybe getting charged higher than locals sometimes but it was never ridiculous.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some anons in this thread have no idea what they're talking about.

Even though the power grid shuts off at night, most businesses and people have generators. There are nightclubs and there's nightlife.
There aren't any significant food shortages, you can go into any shop and buy any food you want. There are also hundreds of great restaurants.
There's some cooming in Lebanon since 1/3 of the country isn't even Muslim, but from my experience the girls are strangely more vapid than their western counterparts.

However, that doesn't mean everything is sunshine and rainbows. There's garbage everywhere, you can only pay with cash due to the currency exchange rules (if you try to use any sort of card you're going to pay 1000x more), you can't drink tap water, everyone is going to give you the tourist price if they realise you're a foreigner, and the Hezbollah controlled areas can be a bit sensitive.
Like the other anon said, Uber is good, just avoid Bolt at all costs. Their trips are cheaper on the app but the drivers will actually charge you more before you reach your destination and if you don't pay whatever they want they'll probably leave you in the middle of nowhere.
HAGGLE FOR EVERYTHING. Don't accept whatever price they first tell you, that's valid for Lebanon and the rest of the Arab world.

In general, just don't play the fool and you'll be fine. It's not an amusement park where you can do whatever you want with no repercussions, like western Europe, but it's nowhere near as dangerous as some people in this thread make it out to be.

If you have any questions just ask

>>2378776
This sounds about right.

You can make India as cheap or as expensive as you'd like. Personally, I think $50-60 per day is a good range for travelers who want to be reasonably comfortable and not have to constantly pinch pennies.

For about $50-60 per day, you can get:
>reasonably nice hotel room (2-3 stars) or Airbnb
>mix of street food and mid-range restaurant food
>private and public transportation (Uber+Metro)
>enough money to have a few drinks in the evening or on the weekends
>money for entrance fees and general sightseeing
>souvenirs and okay-quality handicrafts

You can obviously survive on much, much less money. If you're staying in a hostel dorm, for instance, you probably don't need more than $20-25 per day, assuming the dorm bed costs $8-10.

Fuck--you can basically live on $1-5 per day if you Couchsurf/stay in mosques/stay in gurudwaras and only eat street food. It's fucking India, most people outside of big cities are living on like $2-3 per day. Just don't expect that you can maintain a comfortable standard of living on these sorts of budgets.

However, I do think any strict budget of less than $20 per day is going to entail some significant sacrifices, especially for people who want to do adventure sports, visit a lot of monuments, etc. When you're spending closer to $50-60+ per day, you won't have the budget to stay in a 4- or 5-star hotel, but you can do pretty much everything else without having to think twice about your finances (within reason, of course).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378901
As a quick follow-up, if you're traveling in the country, money obviously goes a lot further. I regularly travel to East-Central India and stay in homestays. In one of the villages I frequent, there are like 2-3 different homestays. The rates are like:
>$7-8 per night for an entire mud house (sounds primitive but actually p comfortable)
>$3-4 per day for food (3 meals per day)
>$8-9 for a guide / someone to drive you around wherever you want (not necessary, but helpful if you want to visit hardcore ooga-booga areas etc)
>$3-4 per day for motorbike, fuel separate (I usually take my own bike)

so for about $20-30 per day, you have accommodation, transportation, and food completely covered

also worth bearing in mind that a lot of dirt-cheap hotels simply do not accept foreign guests, especially in smaller cities in rural areas. this has much less to do with xenophobia than local law, which requires anyone hosting a foreign national to submit a report (Form C) to law enforcement within 24 hours of the guest's arrival. most hotels just don't want to bother, since you have to create an account on the e-FRRO website and it takes like 10-20 minutes on a shitty internet connection to enter all the info

ofc, it's still india so you can accomplish just about anything with the right amount of money + patience

>Would that be enough to live in Mumbai comfortably?
Yes. However, rental prices in Mumbai are significantly more expensive than elsewhere in India. You'll pay more and get less than you would in Delhi or Bangalore. However, an Rs. 60,000 housing stipend should be sufficient alone to rent a reasonably comfortable apartment.

If you're staying or working in a more central area, paying an additional $200-300 out-of-pocket should net you a spacious, modern property.

>How easy is it to travel to other parts of India from Mumbai?
Mumbai is a Tier-1 city and Alpha global city. It has an international airport with flights across the country. You can also take the train to most places. There are regular buses--across a variety of budgets--running to other cities in Maharashtra, Goa, and so forth.

>And how easy is it to make friends/date as a Westerner?
Completely depends on you. Making friends in India is reasonably easy. However, the sorts of people who are most likely to approach you in the street will be interested in you because you're "different." You can sometimes meet decent people this way, but you might not have anything in common. Furthermore, they might simply want to show you off as their "cool foreign friend."

Dating is a slightly different story. Living in India longer-term makes dating easier, especially if you're looking for something serious--many women won't want to go out with someone who's only here for a few weeks or a few months.

Other than that, well--it completely fucking depends on you. You can certainly find White fetishists in a city like Mumbai--girls who only date White men, and will sleep with any reasonably attractive foreigner. They're a very small percentage of the overall population, but if you look half-decent, they'll proactively seek you on dating apps.

I met some of these women when I was single, and they are fucking insufferable. But if you're just looking to get laid, they'll give you what you want.

>>2396301
Samefag who lives in India.

I've traveled to many Naxal-affected villages. You can't just "visit" a Naxalite camp. Outside of a scarce few areas, the Maoists do not maintain any permanent military outposts. During the monsoon, they usually entrench themselves in sympathetic villages that cannot be easily accessed by outsiders, including the Indian security forces. For the rest of the year, and especially in the winter, they camp in rugged jungles during the day and then move into hamlets for provisions and support at night.

While the Naxalites do have something akin to a "parallel government" in parts of Dandakaranya--do a Google search for "Abujmarh"--outsiders cannot simply stroll in for a tour. You will almost certainly be detained and turned around by the CRPF, District Reserve Guard, or another state security force. Even if you pay a local to help you around established checkpoints, you wouldn't get much farther inland without a genuine contact and legitimate connections.

Here's what would most probably happen: once you enter a so-called "liberated zone," you'd be stopped by sympathetic villagers or members of a local Maoist militia. You probably can't speak Hindi, so you wouldn't be able to explain why you're there. Even if you can speak Hindi, you wouldn't be allowed to travel within a Naxal-dominated area unless you'd received prior "permission" from higher-ranking Maoists. You'd be kept overnight and then told to leave the area in the morning.

Conceivably, you could just go "hiking" across Bailadila and "accidentally" end up across the Sukma border. But even if you came across the Naxalites, they wouldn't be willing to entertain some random, retarded foreigner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396766
cont.
You'd be interrogated, held overnight, and--again--told to piss off at first light. In a worst-case scenario, they could use you as a bargaining chip (although the Naxalites have only held foreign tourists for ransom once in the last 50-60 years--and that kidnapping was staged by a former Naxalite commander who had already been kicked out of the main Maoist organization for provoking communal violence in Odisha).

If you know the right people--journalists, villagers, and so forth--they could take you to heavily-affected areas. But if any word got back to any government official that your stupid ass was actively trying to meet Maoists, you'd almost certainly be either deported or restricted from ever re-entering India.

I cannot adequately express how heavily militarized certain parts of Jharkhand, Odisha, and Chhattisgarh area. In so-called "hardcore" Naxal areas, there are police encampments every 2-3 kilometers. If you try to circumvent said encampments, you will probably be stopped by villagers. In certain parts of Abujmarh and adjacent areas, there is also a minute risk that you could step on a landmine or improvised explosive device.

It's really not a good idea.

However, you can still very easily visit peripheral areas as a tourist--and that's something I'd really recommend doing, because many parts of Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand have incredibly unique tribal cultures. Tribal people are usually very honest, very cordial people--they won't stare at you or ask for selfies, and will treat you with the utmost respect if you show the same to them. It's also a good way to gain a basic understanding of on-the-ground conditions without exposing yourself to risks you don't understand.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2395950
>>how safe is it to walk alone as a man in small towns in India?
Generally very safe, with some exceptions. Just do a bit of research on the places you're going beforehand.

In parts of North India--especially rural Bihar, Jharkhand, and Madhya Pradesh--there are still gangs of bandits, who are colloquially called "dacoits." The usual advice in such areas is to avoid any and all travel after sunset. Of course, you'd probably be fine if you were taking public transportation or simply walking around the periphery of a village.

Just be aware that finding accommodation in smaller towns can be difficult, since many budget hotels aren't willing to fill out the paperwork needed to host foreign guests.
>>What is the security situation like in Kanchipuram (small town with lots of temples)?
Never been, but I'm sure it's just fine, lol. You really don't need to worry about traveling around most parts of India if you're a man. I've been here 20+ times and have lived here for years. I had a phone pickpocketed once; I've never had any other problems.
>>how reliable are ATMs if you have a foreign card?
Hit and miss. You're usually fine with:
>State Bank of India (SBI)
>HDFC
>ICICI Bank

... those are just the three I can think of off the top of my head. I have an Indian bank account, so this isn't something I've had to worry about or think about in several years. If memory serves me right, SBI has become somewhat less reliable for foreign cardholders than it used to be. However, SBI is one of a very few banks that doesn't typically charge foreign card-holders any withdrawal fee, provided that you're smart enough to decline the dynamic currency conversion offer.
>>how nice are the trains in India? I might travel to Kanchipuram by train from Puducherry but I could also get a taxi if the trains are bad.
Trains are fine, but--as with everything here--it completely depends on the route and train.

posts.name: Anonymous
