cont.
Certain categories of trains have higher priority and better service than others. Rajdhani and Shatabdi trains, for instance, are usually better-maintained and considerably more punctual than lower-priority trains. I have no clue about services between Pondicherry and Kanchipuram. I doubt it's a very long ride, and I doubt you'd have to deal with much inconvenience.

Overall, you'll usually be at least somewhat comfortable if you book a berth in:
>1AC: highest category of travel, have to share a private, lockable "coupe" with one other passenger. Good service on most Rajdhani and Shatabdi trains, variable on others (air-conditioned)
>2AC: 2x2 berths in main cabin, 2x2 berth on the side (air-conditioned)
>3AC: 3x3 berths in main cabin, 2x2 berth on the side (air-conditioned)

Sleeper is non-AC and very inexpensive, but you'll have to deal with a bit more hassle in terms of retarded passengers, regular beggars, and obnoxious shemale beggars. Non-AC and general can be a clusterfuck, but you'll probably have tons of random people to talk to.

I'd recommend looking for whatever /n/ thread the other anon mentioned.

Just be aware that booking last-minute train tickets as a foreign tourist can be a pain in the ass, since most booking websites don't accept foreign credit cards. I think the IRCTC website only lets you make payments through the ATOM portal more than 48-72 hours in advance. However, they have a new Amex payment portal, and I've been able to use my U.S.-issued Amex card on that without any issues. You can sometimes circumvent payment restrictions on third-party websites using AmazonPay, but some booking agencies, like RedBus, recnetly closed this loophole and now block wallet payments made in foreign currencies.

(the ATOM portal may now be defunct--I didn't see the option the last time I paid for train tickets. Again, I have a local bank account, so some of the shit I'm saying may have been true a few years ago but have since changed)

>>2396772
It's a long story, homie.

The Naxalite insurgency started in a northern district of West Bengal in 1967 before spreading southward toward Kolkata and other urban areas. However, the early Naxalite movement was effectively curbed before and during the political Emergency of the 1970s. During this period, many Naxal sympathizers and cadres were arrested, imprisoned, or summarily executed.

While the initial movement was waning in Bengal, hardcore Maoist sympathizers began actively surveying other regions for the location of a potential "guerrilla base." So far as I can recall, in Maoist war strategy, a guerilla base is an isolated, inaccessible area, from which militants can amass strength and began waging a protracted war of attrition against the urban, industrial state.

Since many early Naxalite cadres were Telugu speakers, they began making inroads into isolated tribal communities in East-Central India. The Gonds, for example, are among the largest tribes in the region; their language doesn't have any widely-used written alphabet. However, since Gondi is somewhat similar to Telugu, the Telugu-speaking cadres were able to gradually learn the language and begin "fixing" certain problems relating to corruption and resource exploitation.

Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, the Naxalites began establishing a significant presence in the historical Dandakaranya region. Much of this region has been neglected by governments for hundreds of years, from the Mughals to the Raj to the early, post-Independence administrations.

Today, the Maoists find the most support among tribal people--people who might not understand or care about the Maoists' ideological values, but believe that their lifestyles and cultures are being threatened by the state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396777
cont.
For context, the most heavily-affected regions, in Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh, are incredibly rich in mineral resources. When the anti-Maoist Salwa Judum militia formed in 2006, tens of thousands of tribal people were displaced from villages that--oh so coincidentally--happened to be of interest to domestic and international mining corporations.

At this point, it's less about ideology, and more about tribal people trying to preserve their rights to "jal, jangal, jameen" (water, jungle, land). I've visited villages wherein the locals used to support the Maoists until they successfully petitioned the government for land titles, after which they cut contact with the guerillas.

If you're interested in the topic, check out "Hello, Bastar" by Rahul Pandita and "Nightmarch" by Alpa Shah. They're both very informative books written by people who have worked extensively in Maoist-affected areas. They're also written for lay audiences, unlike many publications on the topic.

Just be aware that most writings on the insurgency tend to be at least somewhat biased toward one side or the other; the same is true for media coverage. You'll find a lot of left-wing whacko academics who suck the Naxalites' figurative cocks, and just as many right-wing nationalists who are incapable of understanding that Maoist violence is underscored by genuine grievance.

tl;dr: early Maoist sympathizers, especially in the late 1960s and early 1970s, were actual ideologues. Today, most Maoist sympathizers are tribal people who want to protect their land rights and social/cultural autonomy. Most of them don't have any meaningful understanding of Maoist ideology, and simply see the Naxalites as a convenient buffer to state encroachment.

(it's worth mentioning that the Maoists actively hamper assistive development efforts, preventing tribal people from having easy access to effective healthcare and educational institutions--it's not a very complicated, very delicate situation)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

Yes, the road between Dushanbe and Khujand is the major road of Tajikistan, so they go through great pains to keep it open the whole year.
On the way you'll pass through the infamous Anzob tunnel, nicknamed "the tunnel of death" because it was operating for ten year while unfinished, but since about 2016 this is not the case any more, now it's just another long tunnel with the usual traffic dangers present in the region.

If you want to be absolutely sure to keep to your schedule you can plan to go via Termez/Samarkand/Oybek in Uzbekistan, their roads and rails are open all year round without major problems.

The people in the region are conservative and there's a big gap between rural and city people.
In the countryside, "dating" will consist of convincing the village elders that you're a suitable groom, a very difficult task unless you have spent significant time there and have immersed in the local language and culture.
In cities you'll face the typical dating pattern found in more conservative countries: The man leads the date and pays for everything and the woman tries to look her best.
Many young locals do know some English but are hesitant to speak, with many of them becoming quite fluent speakers once they're drunk.
Even women with a liberal worldview are sexually conservative and like to show off their housewife skills by wanting to feed you with food they cook, showing off their bargaining skills or even offering to fix the shirt you tore during your date.
You will also quickly get to know her brothers/cousins/friends who will invite you to their activities consisting of drinking, smoking and all kinds of sports and physical activities to judge you for themselves.
Speaking Russian and/or the local language will definitely help your chances in all stages of the process.

Hey OP,

I want to spend like 3 months in Central Asia and take the chance to learn Russian. My current level is elementary, I only know the alphabet , the numbers, and a couple of greeting questions.

What would be the best country to find a very cheap but efficient Russian school, to study like, 20 hours per week, in a classroom?

Also, suppose I stay 2 months learning Russian, which of the five stans should I choose to live that long?

Lastly, what's the cost of living in each one of them? Is 1k USD enough for a person for a month? What country is the cheapest and which one is most expensive?

Thanks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2392578
Your best bet would be to spend your two months studying in Bishkek.
There are a couple reasons why:
- welcoming visa-free regime, 60 days for citizens of many countries, easy visa runs if you want to stay longer
- Russian is the lingua franca, the locals speak it well and without hesitation
- there are multiple language schools catering to foreign students like you, both short-term and long-term, offering group and private lessons
- there are many teachers and tutors available to hire

As for costs, you can easily keep your expenses at 1000 dollars or less if you compromise a bit by either staying a bit outside the city centre, not eating out every meal or pregaming before going out in the evening.
Even if you don't compromise at all, you will not spend much more in Bishkek.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2392578
>Also, suppose I stay 2 months learning Russian, which of the five stans should I choose to live that long?
I would base myself in Bishkek in a small apartment and take private lessons at one of the schools so that you can easily take extended weekend trips in the region, both in Kyrgyzstan and nearby Southern Kazakhstan.
Almaty is only about 4 hours away (door-to-door) and both FRU and ALA have flights to nearby cities if you are not keen on riding taxis, buses or trains for long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Will be in Astana in 2 weeks. Any advice? What should I see outside of the obvious?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393052
Since you'll be there in the middle of winter prepare to spend most of your time indoors, as Astana weather can be unforgiving with double-digit negative temperatures and strong gusts of wind.
Definitely plan some time for museums, the National museum can take you half a day, the Military museum is interesting & free and who knows how long the Nazarbayev museum will stay open.
Definitely take a look at all the weird buildings that were placed in the city within the last 5 years, in summer you can walk around all day, in winter you will want to do that by taxi as the bus system is not very suitable for tourists and distances are surprisingly large.
As for hanging out, pick any of the malls for people watching, the Khan Shatyr has an indoor amusement park and paid beach.
The "old part of town" North of the river feels more like a Kazakh city, the Artem bazar is where you can get most of your shopping done, including the tasty salads traditionally sold at bazars all over Central Asia.

As for food, the various food courts can be surprisingly good, if you're tired of Kazakh food try Daredzahni for Georgian food, there's a Ukrainian restaurant nearby as well.

>>2393941
That Pegasus overnight flight arriving at 05:00 in the morning isn't bad, just try to get sleepy before boarding and the 5 hours will just fly by.
The plane is fairly new and any delay will only make you arrive closer to daytime.

Remember to not pay more than 700~800 som for the taxi ride to the city, always negotiate before getting into the taxi, if you can get Yandex Taxi installed on your phone before arriving you'll have an even easier time.
Worst case you can take the shuttle bus into town, costs around 200 som and runs every 20 minutes, just take a left after customs.

You can get both SIM cards and cash in the airport, there are SIM card vendors accepting KGS/USD/EUR between passport control and baggage claim as well as outside, plus a load of ATMs without ripoff rates just to the right after customs.

Have fun and try not to get too smoked by the winter air!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393984
I'd definitely try to check in early, with or without paying for an additional night.
Pretty much all places have a night guard, so you will not stand in front of locked doors in the morning.

>How cash/cashless is Kyrgystan?
Very cash-based. There are more and more places where you can pay by card, but it's usually quicker to just pay cash, unlike Kazakhstan where QR payments are getting the norm.
I usually pay big expenses by card and anything else cash, carrying about KGS 5000 (about USD 60) with me in my wallet, another 5000 back at home.
There are two banks, Halyk and Optima that will allow you ATM withdrawals without additional commission.
>I guess I'll buy a SIM card at the airport.
Good idea, you can set up everything while waiting for your luggage to come out plus the airport vendors speak some English.
Currently O! has the best offers, but check the Prepaid SIM card wiki for details.
>In Turkey, it was a pain in the ass to get a SIM card anywhere else.
In Kyrgyzstan they literally give them away for free at border crossings and you can buy them anywhere in the city.
> Am I right to assume that Ala Too Square is the very heart of the city?
Yeah, but anywhere on Prospekt Chuy can be considered central.
Anything in the square between Zhibek Zholu in the North, Alamedin River in the East, the railroad in the South and Osh bazar to the West is easily reached on foot or by countless buses/marshrutkas.
There's a coal power plant to the East, keep that in mind in terms of air pollution, the South has cleaner air, but if you're sensitive you should avoid Bishkek in winter anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393984
>I found a well reviewed hostel near Osh Bazaar for like $100 per week which seemed like a good deal.
Osh bazar is considered to be the sketchiest part of Bishkek but personally I have been there at all times of the day and night and did not have any troubles or felt unsafe.
As usual, don't give pickpockets a chance and keep your valuables at home, but being from Brazil you should already know that, no offence.
The biggest actual danger is traffic and uneven pavements, make sure you watch where you're going.

>I plan on finding a Russian language course
What schools are you considering?
I've heard good things from both the London School and LinguaYurt with their programmes for foreigners, both group classes and individual lessons.
There are some cheaper schools as well targeted at locals, usually offering Russian, Turkish and English, but from what I've heard you'll be in bigger classes studying together with rural Kyrgyz on how to speak enough Russian to be a migrant labourer in Russia.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395382
Been there last year, I will summarize:

Tolls EVERYWHERE, factor that into travel costs, probably paying about 10 euro every 100 km.
Look for quieter spots that dont have tons of "foreign" tourists, my personal favourite was Kamena Vourla - it was mostly greeks on domestic holidays. Second favourite was Mytikas because it was much quieter than others.
Many of the roads and streets are poor and the drivers are crazy so always keep it in the back of your head to be careful.
Snacks are expensive, you want a bottle of coke? Some places sell 500ml cokes for 3 euro.
There are quite varying temperatures across the country, next to the ocean is generally cooler but in the midlands it can be agonizingly hot.
If driving, make sure to visit petrol stations often, lots of them close on a Sunday too so don't get stuck!
The Greeks are very kind (when they are not driving) and will talk to you if they can, some even took us home and were very hospitable.
Pay attention to google maps - if you are sure you have the right place but the journey says it takes a crazy long time, there is likely a valid reason (landslides etc).
A lot of places do not let you put normal toilet roll in the toilet - I wish I was kidding but they expect you to shit, wipe, and put your shitty wipes in the bin next to the toilet. This was honestly the most disgusting thing about Greece, I didn't even see one bidet.

posts.com:
>>2395382
• Greek food is the best, focus on grilled meat, fish
• Try desserts: galatopita, bougatsa, galaktoboureko
• Greek fast food is patrician. It's hard for foreign fast food companies to get a foothold because local fast food is so good. The go-to is Gyro or meaet skewers(kalamaki).
• They got some bomb ass sour cherry drinks and sodas. Try the sour cherry one from Loux, amazing.
• Try feta from a barrel. The Olympos one from a grocery store is good.
• In Athens there are a lot of amazing eateries at all price ranges.
• Avoid tourist traps and people who holler at you to sit in their place.
• Unlike spain that barely has 30-50% (depending on area) of households with air conditioning, Greece has 99%. Who's the third country now?
• Greece is a bit far behind technologically and many roads are completely shit. It's not great for shopping either. Around Athens' Kolonaki there are some shops though like Balenciaga and high-end watches boutiques. You won't find Uniqlo though.
• Greeks are super nice
• Some Greeks have inferiority complex and are whiny bitches. The lowest class ones are nearer middle-eastern in their behavior instead of more north/western. Kefalonia and islands around the Ionian sea are colored by Italian heritage and genetics. They were never controlled by the Ottomans either. Completely different from the Cyrpean mutts or people from south Aegean islands.

cont.

• These people usually have residences around the Attica region, summer house(s) on islands, yatch(s), residences in US east coast, UK, southern france, Switzerland. You won't meet these people though since they're very insulated.

People there are a bit tougher and there's a Vendetta culture going on reminiscent of Italy. Often you'll see signage that has holes in it because of a shoot-out. They might be a bit taller and have blue eyes. Different phenotype.
• Athens is basically many generations of different socio-economic backgrounds stacked on top of each other so there are stark differences of income. Someone who works in the shipping industry and does well might make north of 200k USD while an average person might struggle to get by with 800USD a month working at a grocery store clerk and never getting enough money to move out of the family home.
• Distances in Athens can be quite large and the center is living hell during summer because of all the concrete that makes it like an over. During June-August, try to avoid Athens or keep it short or do activities after the sun sets.
• Transport is not that good in Athens, just use Uber.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395382
The islands are all nice, but many are a bit dull. There really isn't a whole lot to do on them and once youve seen one or two you've seen all. If you like quieter islands with hiking I could highly recommend Amorgos. Santorini is pretty incredible and worth visiting. If you want a party island then Ios or Mykonos are your best options.

The comment about staying on the mainland but staying coastal is a good one. In the Peloponnese you have places like Nafplio which are beautiful and highly worth a couple of nights. Sparta was interesting but one night was enough (mystras near by well worth 1/2 day).

Olympia is ok for the main site, but a tourist trap overall. Delphi was interesting too. But touristy but interesting for sure. There is a little town below Delphi called Galaxidi that is great for lunch.

Athens is really the highlight. You can stay cheaply in the center area and be within walking distance of all the best stuff.

My recommended itinerary for 2 weeks would be something like:

> Athens 1 night
> Get ferry boat down to a couple of islands (2 nights on each)
> Ferry back to Athens (2 nights to explore Athens)
> Hire car and drive around Peloponnese visiting Nafplio (2 nights), Sparta/Mystras (1 night)
> Olympia (1 night)
> Delphi (1-2 nights)
Athens (1 night) -> home.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2397919
Food sucked, idk where people are getting the idea that Greek food is good. It’s okay at best. Even at “high end” traditional Greek places I didn’t find it all too good. Seafood is okay.
Most of the cool stuff in Athens can be seen in a couple days, a week at most. I walked around most of the city and there really isn’t much to see besides the acropolis and the surrounding archeological sights, the acropolis museum, etc. The nightlife is pretty mediocre by all standards, most neighborhoods are quite rundown and don’t look anything like the islands. If I could do it again, I’d go in the summer and only stay in Athens for maybe 3 or 4 days, then spend the rest of the time touring the islands. Greece is just kinda meh in the off seasons, I posted about it here before but I just felt like an inconvenience, i met a handful of friendly people but nowhere near what I experienced in other European countries. It really wasn’t too different from turkey in terms of standoffish-ness, and frankly the service in turkey was way better. I had this rosie idea of what Athens would be like based on all the historical sites I had read about looked like, but most of those are renderings, and the mainland looks nothing like the pictures of islands in OPs picrelated.
TLDR Athens for a few days max then hit the islands, preferably during summer season otherwise it will be very dead and boring

If you care fuck all about ancient history, then probably not. If you do, there are lots of other ancient megaliths as equally impressive as the pyramids. Temples of Karnak, Hatshepsut, underground tombs in Luxor, Abu Simbel. And even I, a complete dumbass, could appreciate the museums.
On actual fun hoodrat shit, there plenty of spots to scuba dive in the red sea. It's really beautiful and warm even in the winter, and they don't care if you aren't certified. You can rent a quad for pretty much nothing and rip it across the desert in Hurghada. Or rent a scooter and ride it all over the country.
Yes Egypt and especially Cairo is a shithole, and you will be harassed constantly, but I actually really liked the shittiness and chaos of it. Wish I had spent more time there.

Outside observation: It was always a racist country. It was simply slightly less racist than its southern neighbor, the United States.

Canada’s historical mistreatment of its First Nations citizens is on display for the world to see. While the nation had reached some accommodations with the various tribes, it’s still very clear that the First Nations people are viewed as being second class citizens in many areas of Canada, particularly in areas with large populations of tribal members. The poor state of infrastructure on many of the reserves also clearly indicate that the government’s priority is not the residents of those areas.

As far as Blacks: While Canada was never as racist as the Deep South of the United States, segregation (de jure and de facto) were very common in Canada until the 1960s. Black Canadians who descended from either people brought over as slaves, former sea farers and escaped American slaves, lived in segregated areas, faced discrimination for jobs and financing and were often harassed by law enforcement and White Canadians. While this changed drastically in the last 50 years ( due in part to changes in the US and an influx of Afro-Carribbeans and African immigrants and refugees) , racism is not uncommon in areas of Canada which have small non-White populations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393549
Asians - Both East and South Asians have experienced a great deal of discrimination in Canada, although the fact that many came to Canada with wealth or were able to move into the middle and upper classes within a generation or so seems to have tempered this somewhat. Just as in the United States, most Asians and their descendants live in and around the major cities and urban areas, so the prejudice that they experience isn’t as widespread as the prejudice against Blacks and First Nations people seems to be. It does , however exists as referenced below.

Latinos - The recent influx of Latinos into the country seems to have provoked some prejudice against. However, Canada’s Latino population is relatively small, most confined to the cities, and it really hasn’t integrated into the mainstream. As climate change worsens and it becomes clear that Canada can support many more people than its harsh winters currently allows, there are likely to be more immigrations from Latino majority nations which are likely to face the need to flee that change. If history is any indicator if/when their numbers increase, so will the prejudice and discrimination that they face.

Canada is not a bad country, and its racism isn’t as profound as it is in many areas of the United States. It’s not “turning racist.” It IS racist, but it is also slightly less so than many other countries in the Western world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2398979
Actually pretty solid, acknowledging that D*blin is not a place to stay for longer than a couple of days. That being said I'd add the Croke Park Museum and swap out Temple Bar for Camden Street (better pubs and restaurants there in what's not as much of a tourist trap).
Then for Kilkenny if you're driving to it you could go to Glendalough as a detour, that and/or Kildare Town (for the Japanese Gardens, Kildare Village etc.)
Cork is fine but just stay out of the city it's shit. You might as well to to the Jameson brewery and maybe Malin Head but that's better to do on the way to Kerry.
Speaking of I can't say much for Kerry. Don't bother going to Dingle to see Fungie because that fucker's dead.
Limerick's decent but definitely a day trip.
If you have the chance/time the Aran Islands might be worth trying for a view of rural island life.
Galway - you need more than a day on this and the surrounding area. Clifden is worth the trek out and the Killary Fjords (the only ones in Ireland) are a good sight. Also Kylemore Abbey. Galway city alone is a day along with the rest of these.
Potentially go up to Sligo as well it's underrated. Donegal has some nice stuff.
Every county/city/area not mentioned in your itinerary or my recommedations is not worth even looking at, especially the midlands which are some nice scenery and absolute shitholes of towns, and doubly so for most D*blin suburbs (also Louth).
Generally speaking look out for the wide array of B&Bs available in some of the locations, there's probably good stuff on offer. A hostel might be the best thing to do for Dublin if you don't want to spend at least 100 on a hotel room (which you will).
There's only certain drives that take a long time and all of them you have broken up in your itinerary so in general it should be fine to drive.

Yeah it's a bit of a weird place, you have to fly into Belize city which is a total dump with nothing going for it and take a slow boat / flight out to the cays which are epic. It sounds like you've already booked so I don't wanna be a doomer but of all the central American countries its by far the most expensive for everything - possibly bar Costa Rica. Still if you're going you'll have fun, the hotel we stayed at had a reef about 1/2 a km out and they had kayaks you could use so we'd just kayak out every day and attach it to the buoy and snorkel for hours.
There's an amazing diversity of sea life there and there's always the blue hole which if you're new I wouldn't suggest - perhaps by the time you've passed but it's other worldly. Enjoy yourself

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401758
So I've travelled most of south and Central America but for what you say you're after I would strongly recommend going to the Caribbean coast of Colombia. You say you have dollars so I'm assuming you're a burger, you can get relatively cheap flights to Bogota then bus up to Cartagena, when I was there (admittedly it was years ago) it was the cheapest place pretty much in the world to do your Padi. $200 for the whole course, dives, lunches and you got to meet cool people, there's also a bunch of good hostels and overall it's a great vibe, once you're done you can also head to the national park and live cheap Robinson Crusoe style, it's very kino, pretty sure it was called tyrona and it was up the coast from Cartagena.
Belize in comparison is expensive, don't get me wrong the diving is great but you have to fly or boat out the cays and then it's mostly expensive hotels, I did cat caulker and then a few other places, can't remember the name, it was nice but not sure it's for the bang for you buck that Colombia has.
Also the blue hole if I'm remembering correctly is about 40 metres deep, when you take your first Padi which in guessing is still called the open water it only allows you on dives down to 30 metres. To get down further your need your advanced. Don't get me wrong there will be dodgy people who will take you without it but not really worth the risk imo, sure you could snorkel the surface but kinda boring.
I've not been to Bonaire but I did Honduras, pretty cool and they have awesome whale sharks but it's a bit trickier to get there and all in all unless you're just in the area it's a faff. I'd defo say do Colombia, it's awesome

posts.com: Anyone going to be in Vegas this month? I'm going in a few weeks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few things I learnt from my trip:

Stock up on drinks and snacks at Walgreens or Target next to the MGM, don't buy any cans, bottles or snacks at a hotel.

Fremont Street and Circus Circus are both complete bitches to get to. Don't expect to walk to them or be able to get the monorail to them.

The buffets are terrible value for money now and half of them a "brunch" buffets which mean they're split between breakfast and lunch so the range suffers. Maybe do one for the novelty but just eat at regular restaurants for the rest, you'll get better food and you can still fill yourself up and have it come out cheaper.

If you're a light sleeper, either get some white noise generator or turn the fan on the AC up. Noisy drunk people and heavy doors that slam hard are a bitch.

Older and smaller strip hotels gaming floors either have eye watering levels of cigarette smoke or pump out huge amounts air freshener to counter it. If you're intending to use your hotel to game and can't deal with smoke, don't stay at one of the cheap "classic" strip hotels.

Comp drinks servers all but run past you in my experience. You have to be proactive or at least keep a look out to get drinks.

I ended up using the monorail far more than I was expecting. It's worth getting a multi-day ticket if you're at a hotel that has a station. There are various ways of getting discounts (MyVegas lets you exchange easy to get points for vouchers and the monorail vouchers are one of the better vouchers you can earn that isn't always out of stock).

Slots are low odds and low volatility (at least on the strip). Very unlikely they'll do anything other than slowly drain away your money.

Bluffing is a much smaller part of poker than you'd think. Call with OK hands, raise with good hands. You should be folding 75% of your hands at least. If you have a strong starting hand, don't limp. At lower limit tables the guy who raises first preflop (unless he gets re-raised) wins most hands

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395044
>Lowest possible volitility:
You play $1 and the reels come in $0.85 every single spin. Most of the money paid out by the slot goes on low wins

>Highest possible volitility:
Every 1,100,000 spins, it wins $1,000,000 and never wins outside of that. Most of the money paid up by the slot goes on high win

US slots are basically all low X bet wins. They may have $10,000 jackpots but they never pay out on low stakes and even if people play the max stakes of ~$4 you're still going to go an entire holiday never having seen anyone hit then (and a 2500x max win is considered low for a slot) . Most people will see a steady stream of < 10x wins and features that almost never go above 50x.

With low volitility, people play for a long time, but almost no one comes out with a profit. With high volilitility, people who don't win get their money drained quickly but a % of people leave the slots having had a massive win.

Where I’m moving to isn’t a developing nation, it literally has a higher HDI than my region in England, and frankly most regions here in the UK based on the research I’ve done.

On all fronts, it’s very marginally more expensive than my city in the UK, with average wages basically on-par. I can tell you though, 100% positive, as someone who’s used the public services in both countries from the police to public transport to hospitals, the UK is really, really in a bad state and is incredibly piss poor in those aspects despite the fact that we’re apparently ‘more developed’.

The benefit? I get better weather, prettier surroundings, nicer people and a safer more enjoyable living environment.

Is it perfect? Nah, it has it’s problems, just as you suggested. I’m not deluding myself into some fairytale. For me, the benefit of just being able to wake up in the morning, having a coffee on my balcony at my GFs, whilst overlooking the winding old Mediterranean city streets with the sun shining on my face, outweighs anything I’ll find in the UK.

Don’t get me wrong, I can see why plenty of people in the Mediterranean (for example) want to move to somewhere like the UK. It’s got it’s benefits, for unskilled work there’s better pay, and for more niche career fields/opportunities for progression that wouldn’t necessarily exist at home in abundance, even if the quality of life here isn’t anywhere near as good. Most of those people don’t end up settling here though. They’ll come, earn their money, get their experience or education, then head home after a few years once they’re jaded by it all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I went to Italy in the summer. Went from the north down to the south. At first the north was nice, cleaner than I expected, whiter than I expected, and extremely friendly and helpful people. Very nice place.

The south though? I will never forget it. I have never experienced anything like the Amalfi coast before. It felt surreal. It felt like a dream. It felt like I was on mushrooms. The sheer beauty of the land was hard to deal with. Every five minutes I'd be faced with the most beautiful landscape I'd ever seen. I know on my deathbed I will remember my drive from Naples to Positano along those winding volcano roads. No other experience I've had on this planet can compare to that in terms of sheer natural beauty.

Naples itself was kind of a dump, very rundown and grimy which was very off-putting at first but after growing accustomed to it it became charming in a way. And I will always have love for Naples based on nothing more than the pizza, which, over the course of a three country two week trip throughout Europe was BY FAR the best food we ate. It was stunning how cheap and amazing the food was. At a plastic table where I brushed cigarette ash off of my plate and Indian kids screamed wildly in the streets, where haggard old women hung out of windows smoking and scooters zipped around dangerously, I had the best meal in my entire life.

Italy is amazing. The south of Italy is beyond amazing.

if you want to stay longer than 3 months in one stay you need a residence permit. To get a residence permit you need an local address, EU passport, proof of funds/income, and european healthcare card. You fill out some paperwork, make a picture, and then you get and residence permit id card. It will cost you less than 100 euro and is done in a week. Though would be easier if you get an local lawyer to help you deal with the immigration office and paper work.

I've cycled most countries in Europe, and doing the rest starting in a few months. Some countries multiple times, like through Germany 4-5 times.

I don't really recommend following them, some are straight up unfinished and some go on unpaved roads. It's basically just a route where you can see the most when going through a country.
Maybe the Spanish ones are good to follow, as there are fair amount of roads you're not allowed to cycle or you have to take some dirt road next to them.

Some of them are just boring. For example Barcelona - Vienna route, I went to Andorra from Barcelona, skipped the coast. Then come down from the mountains and follow east to Italy. Hit up Milan and go past Lake Como to Switzerland. Italy is awful to cycle, especially the coast, so better to get out as fast as possible.

I will also be solo travelling in Rome mid Feb.

Just book a hostel, although I booked mine about a month ago and it was nearly already fully booked then. So you might have some trouble getting somewhere at short notice.
Who you get in your room is pot luck, but its pretty much certain there will be at least some other solo travellers.
My last solo trip everyone in the room was solo, which I think was by design, but I'm not sure how many other hostels do that.

If you're friendly and confident and are not an ugly socially awkward freak then people will be more than willing to chat to you and probably go out for a meal and or drinks.
Just say hi to whoever's in the room when you walk in. Group travellers in your room may well also let you join up with them, its just a bit less common because sometimes they want to get on with their own thing.
Privacy wise try and get a hostel that has a curtain that goes across your bed, if you can't then it shouldnt be too much of a problem anyway, especially only for a few days.

Worth noting that its Valentines day on the 14th, I was slightly worried that the rooms would just be a bunch of couples, but I expect not because that's hardly very romantic.
On the positive side the single girls might be a lot more up for being romanced.

posts.com:
Hey OP, am also half and half

I was making 200-400rmb an hour in Beijing 2015-2017 as a full-time student. However that was mainly through private lessons, working under the table at a tutoring center, etc..

Basically I'd get a part-time job, work at it for a bit, guanxi with parents, and cut out the middleman. Turn those 150/hr tutoring jobs into 300. Parents and students were fine with my 'racial ambiguity'.

The only time I felt slighted was getting hired for a high school speech course. The pay was good at 500rmb/hr pathed up to a work visa, and too good to be true. Right as classes started the coordinator dropped me from 5 classes to 1 and told me I'd be a substitute teacher. They told me I shouldn't have gotten the job on paper (Chinese last name) but was handsome enough to make it work. Some jobs aren't worth taking

I don't know how flexible the situation is with Student Visa's nowadays but basically everyone I knew who studied hard in China was working on the side. I knew this Bangladeshi guy with a London accent who taught over Wechat. 2 hours a night at 300rmb/hr teaching people barely able to string a sentence together.

At one point I also did apply for a formal workvisa / classroom monkey job, but you have to fight for every bit and piece of your contract. It's always a headache with contracts.

Already spending too much time on this OP, but tldr Parents and Students like mixed-race, schools and companies will use it to bargain against you.

Anyway that's my experiences OP, best of luck

posts.name: Anonymous

Nah, your experience should count for something. My suggestion is to go beyond applying for TEFL jobs (which tend to have strict, even if low, entry bars) and apply for jobs at international schools teaching subjects or grade levels. I got such a job by applying for something I saw on ESLCafe, and many of my fellow teachers were from all around the world - Kazakhs, Lebanese, French, etc. The commonality was being fluent in English.
Mind you, the school was in a country going through something of a civil war, but I used that experience as a springboard for other international schools, despite never having been a licensed teacher or having an education degree.

Your mileage can certainly vary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Please note: I prefer US small towns but it would hurt my heart to rank them.
Also: Many states with great nature cannot be included of course. Natural sites are the #1 reason to visit the usa.

I am from Norway and will rank my top 10 USA cities I have been to:
1) Philadelphia - I love this city because there is history plus excitement. I went to the dangerous ghettos and this is what travel is about - feats of courage. Do you have the courage to go to a black ghetto? How about the drug zones? How about Camden? Yes, Philadelphia is great for other reasons too (historical sights, pretty buildings, etc) but for men this is a must visit to show your courage. In Philly you can see beauty and destitution in one trip.

2) Pittsburgh - Yes, Pennsylvania made a big affect on me. And anyway, what a beautiful city - the bridges, the hills, the rivers. The Cathedral of learning was splendid and there was a felling in the air I could not shake. I love this city.

3) Santa Fe- I love pueblo homes and Santa Fe did not disappoint. And such a great jumping off point to explore the wonderful New Mexico. Such a cultured city.

4) Charleston - This city has real southern charm unlike boring atlanta and it is not as filled as Savannah (which I also loved). Anyway, you should go here for Southern charm absolutely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
5) San Fransisco - Wow this city is beautiful. And for me I felt so magical here. But of course it is also crime ridden and lots of drug addicts. But, as somebody who enjoys feats of courage, this was no problem for me. The fog is enchanting.

6) Las Vegas - I don't even gamble much but this is the strangest city. It is a playground in the desert. And from Las Vegas you can easily reach some great national parks. I loved the feeling of this place very much. It is like a movie.

7) Gary - Can you tell that I love American urban decay? Well, maybe Gary isn't a "city" anymore because of population decline. But you must visit this if you are near Chicago. I was so giddy with excitement the whole time. The aesthetic is post-apocalyptic, absolutely!

8) Boston - A great and historical city. I loved the freedom trail, there is a line on the sidewalk and you simply follow it to see the different historical sights. I think this city is beautiful.

9) San Diego - Los Angeles was a disappointment. San Diego some say is "boring" but it is a nice and safe place. There are no feats of courage here, mostly just relaxing and enjoying this comfortable city.

10) Washington DC - This almost went to Seattle but it has to go to DC. If you are into the truth about Satanic powers then you will enjoy this place. I sense evil here but that makes it invigorating. Like at any moment I could "disappear". Also it is fun to rent the scooters here and go drive around the Georgetown neighborhoods and embassy row. Also, there are great museums and some pretty areas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I studied and worked in China, definitely go if you aren't worried about being locked in there. It's a cool place, people are not really mean to foreigners they just might try to hike the price up if you don't speak Chinese and know how to haggle, and it's only at markets. They are first world, have plenty of food. You won't get served cold water if you eat locally just be aware it will be scolding hot water you can't even drink until you finish eating, they do this to prove the water is clean and because eating cold foods makes you sick in their minds. It's really affordable, if you do work you might be lucky to get a higher wage than locals usually do. I was never without money there, never harassed, never had problems. Yeah sometimes people stare at you. Also during holidays rural people go into the cities and you will be in their photo albums and never see that photo, it's a bit embarrassing but funny. Being blonde, tall, overweight, or black will bring a lot of eyes. I was none of these, but still got attention. Chinese is not hard to learn just hard to write, but you probably will never have to write much.

Also you need special permission to visit west China, you can't just go fyi, in case you were interested.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I spent a week back in September at the JW Marriott in Polanco. Fucking loved it dude. Polanco in general felt pretty safe to me, it's a pretty affluent area from what I gathered.

Xochimilco was nice, a little too touristy for my tastes but it was cool learning about the history behind it. Oh, I speak Spanish fluently so that would help you a ton.

Also did a day trip to Teotihuacán with a local tour guide. Impressive city, be ready for walking because it's fucking huge. If you can't make it, I would skip it tbqh. If you've already seen something on the level of Machu Picchu, you won't really be impressed. Go if you're a history buff.

For things inside the city, I recommend catching a show at the Palacio de Bellas Artes. I forgot the show I watched. It was about Mexican music or culture throughout the ages. The theater itself gets hot as fuck though, I don't think it has AC.

The national museum of anthropology was interesting, felt like a waste of time in general. Again, only go if you're a super history buff. I enjoyed talking to people instead to get their POV on CDMX.

As far as food goes, you really can't go wrong here. Any vlog you see on Youtube will steer you right, I promise you. Casa de los Azulejos was a little "meh" but cool architecture.

Can't answer any monger questions because that's not why I went.

I would skip this area entirely, or just make it a very short trip for a pic or two.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The two cities couldn’t be much more different. Have you ever been to either?

Bangkok is somewhat cheaper, somewhat dirtier, quite a lot hotter, much smoggier (although I’ve been told that there are seasonal air quality problems in TPE too, it was fairly clear on my two visits), and close to five times the size of Taipei. Taipei is a fairly large place, but Bangkok’s much closer to a megacity, and it feels like one. If you’re used to small towns or easily overwhelmed, BKK is probably going to be harder to deal with than Taipei, which is in large part relatively orderly where Bangkok can be chaotic.

Personally, I would rather live in Thailand (I was there for several years, including a year in Bangkok), but I think Taipei is an easier place by a lot of metrics. I prefer the food, and I enjoy a bit of chaos.

English proficiency isn’t particularly good in Thailand outside of relatively narrow tourist areas, and most Thai women are disinclined to date foreigners, in part because they don’t want to be mistaken for prostitutes, who are treated like absolute shit by locals. There are exceptions, including very rich girls, party girls, and girls with their hands out, but no matter what sexpats/sex tourists manage to convince themselves, being a white guy does NOT make you more attractive or interesting in Thailand in general.

Not 100% sure how much better the English is among average Taiwanese, as I’ve always been visiting an expat friend and his Taiwanese wife when I’ve been there, so I both met people who spoke English fairly well and had a handy translator, but my surface impressions are that the average proficiency levels among young people are at least a little higher. And although my sample size is small I had a clear impression that dating white folks isn’t as stigmatized there.

No idea about Taiwanese residency policies, but know that despite its popularity among laptop hobos, Thailand is explicitly not a digital nomad-friendly country.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
Dear /trv/eterans,

I have decided to create a thread for those interested in general information regarding living abroad. I think a lot of threads tend to discuss some singular aspects of living in certain countries, but I feel like regrouping these, no matter if they're country-specific or not, would be worth it, for the sake of archiving interesting information within one single (or a series of thread). This thread is aimed at prospecting beginners.

>Why should I live abroad ?
Many reasons. Cost of life can be better abroad, job opportunities more favorable to your field of work, a society you're more in tune with (safety, values). Other possibilities include doing an academic exchange or a double diploma, maybe an internship of some kind that will enhance your CV to prospective recruiters from your home country (or the one you want to go to.)

>But I don't want to live there forever !
It's fine, most people don't and leave after a few years. You don't have to marry a local, buy a house and stay there forever. Sometimes it's nice to go out there, take it out of your system, then come back all grown up and with some new tricks up your sleeve.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>What do you mean by that ? What do I gain from doing a temporary expatriation?
It really depends on how fruitful it was, but aside from whatever professional experience you've gain from it, by doing you so you have learned to leave your comfort zone, forced yourself into socializing with people who had no reason to talk to you besides speaking English and probably befriended some, negotiated for jobs and deals with people that are completely foreign to you and learned what it truly meant to be alone and be your own island, sometimes. If you came to say, Asia, with nothing more than a high school degree and nothing else but your hands, you've also learned how to network, find a job, and to pay your bills you actually had to learn how to keep that job. Of course, perhaps the conditions that made you get the job in the first place won't be there at home, which will make you stay. But at least you're actually functional now. And you'll be able to figure something out.

>Is immigration/expatriation something I should prepare ?
The more you prepare it, the better. Learning the local language (not necessarily bilingual but every bit helps), acquiring a skill, gathering information on how to get in and what visa schemes are available for you are all too important parts of a successful experience abroad.

>why the tripcode ?
Because I won't LARP. The answer you will receive from me will either be something I know to be true from personal experience. And the tripcode ensures that if I truly am bullshitting you, I can get called out for everything i've said throughout the series of threads that will be posted. It's a win-win.

And with that, the thread begins. If you're experienced, don't hesitate to share your experiences, tips and tricks you know. If you're not, don't hesitate to ask all the questions you want to ask.
P.S : human trafficking solliciters, remember that you're violating US law.

There are ways to do so, it depends on the region and what you are willing to do. In most cases, the answer is no. But in certain cases, Canada has signed WHV program with a certain number of countries. Meaning you can get a visa that allows you to work in the country for 6 months up to a year.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>>2390290
No problem. I'm only talking about Taiwan because that's what I know, and you seem to have either Taiwan or Japan as an endgoal. You won't solve being a shut-in by meeting up open people. You'll solve it by either meeting people who match your energy or truly learning why you can't socialize.

Introverts don't want to talk shop because they think small talk is a thing for retards, when really, small talk is the human way to show that they want to sniff your butt and enter your social circle so they can actually open up to you. Ironically, go really autistic and try to get into deep shit with them and they fucking freak out like anybody else because that's not what normally constituted people do, so damned if you do, and damned if you don't. Other things being invited to go have a meal with a group or with a friend and often refusing, which people understand as a rejection of friendship and not just a circumstantial thing, if repeated more than once.
It doesn't matter where you go, this is true everywhere.

>Are people open to be my friends ?
Since you said you were autistic, i'll tell you how it goes. In general, most people, Taiwanese included, are open to be your friend, provided you have some kind of pretext to meet them. If you don't know anybody, are not partaking in any hobbies and do not have a job yet, why would a perfect stranger befriend you ? Think about this problem, and trying to find some solutions on your own would be a good exercise.

Second, I always recommend people to go out and meet the expats in Taipei. They're a varied, decent bunch, very open, and are present in pretty much every night scene, they understand what it is to be a complete stranger to everyone and having to spontaneously meet new folks, and until you can understand how to make friends with locals, they can also introduce you to some. Internet people (not just 4chan) pretend they snob them but it's really that they've never talked to them.

People always say it's the best way but the way it happens makes it so that it basically never does. MNCs function in such a way that every national branch is its own company. They bill shit to each other, and either compete with, or work in fields that aren't quite the ones back home.

For example, a lot of MNCs will have folks working sales abroad to sell the products produced back home. And the people they will hire are obviously locals because they might be cheaper or just more at ease with communicating with the locals. Also, hiring an equivalent foreign worker is pound to pound as skilled as a local is considered bad practice and is starting to get heavily curbed in Asia.

Therefore, differentiation is key. Differentiation through diplomas (Prestigious ones), differentiation through specialization (PhDs in certain fields of expertise that are needed there, for example, or at least +5 year in a field but more is better).

If you're ballsy enough you can point out a certain need in a foreign branch, explain how to fill it so they can tailor a job offer for you there, too.
This being said, a lot of people manage to get to work abroad if they have +5 years exp in dev, sometimes less. Foreign internships, exchanges and double diplomas during your studies can help if you take the necessary steps professionally to make it work.

In a nutshell, anything that makes you a better person than a local works. And that also goes by evening the playing fields. Some countries have visa schemes that facilitate foreign hiring for skilled workers. Speaking the local language in a professional capacity also helps leveling the playing field and beating other foreign contenders. Again, you don't necessarily need to do all that to try your luck. But I suggest you orient yourself by tailoring yourself to be a competitive foreign worker as you go, which will only better your odds. Also, seriously, the field. Don't go to china with a pol sci degree.

I believe in the material, meat and potatoes. I am interested in the things that I know will bring me happiness. Call me a hedonist if you want, but I refuse to do things that will, further down the line, only bring me depression, contempt for other people, and spend my precious life on this earth.
If there is a more gratifying job, a better partner to be with, a better place to be in, i'll go right there and I see no reason to deprive myself of anything that could be a step up. An argument can be made about what makes it truly a step-up, sure, but it is undeniable that for some people in certain countries, you can really improve your life by going abroad. I actually believe that a temporary experience (which is what an expatriation is, by the way) is nice to have. Discovering foreign cultures in an in-depth way is a life-changing experience and it doesn't have to be a permanent one.

Also, just because you have less value in your country doesn't mean that this value is inherent to you. Maybe being an introverted engineer in a western country that has abandoned its industrial sector translates to being a polite, at ease socially engineer in Taiwan's booming industry ? Maybe being a French chef in France is hardly well paid and recognized because we've got so many of them, but it translates to being a great chef abroad with very interesting and classy recipes ?
In other words, why should an Eskimo who failed at selling popsicles in Alaska be called a failure because he decided to try his luck in Malaysia where the weather's too fucking hot all year around ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395192
>I thought increasingly in asia you require a degree level in whatever to qualify for English teaching at least I thought that was the case in China and Japan.
That is increasingly, and indeed, nearly always the case, and not just in China and Japan. Thailand requires degrees too, has done for years now.

People without degrees but with certifications can still sometimes find work in Thailand, typically either as private tutors or at the sleaziest of private language school sweatshops, but they can’t get work permits or non-immigrant visa sponsorship. So the work (and as often as not, the teachers’ residence) is under the table and officially illegal, with all the risk that implies. It’s been a few years since the last crackdown, but Thai authorities have caught and mass deported English teachers working without proper papers several times that I can remember.

The only place I’ve ever personally known someone to work full-time as a teacher without a degree was Cambodia, but there may be other Wild West possibilities out there.

Still almost certain to run into visa/permit problems, though.

posts.com: how do you find a job abroad? im a young engineer and id like to work in asia for a few years, im a bit clueless on how to find a job postings. i just tried linked in and some googling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395792
Linkedin, indeed. Check on the internet where do people post their job postings for a particular country. Get yourself some letters of recommendation. References are also ok but since some employers might not care since they can't really believe them, having some letters right off the bat can be a plus for these cases.
Possibly translate your CV.

If a country seriously strikes your fancy, you could try to go there for a week or two with the sole goal of networking. Meet literally anyone with the largest common denominator, aka alumnis, then dudes in your field you might meet in expat bars that are from your home country, and just ask around for pointers and tips (never directly for a job). Also, read up on this process of networking so you don't sound like a scummy hustler.


Add a lot of recruiters on linkedin from the particular country in the companies that interest you.

If you can arrange some interviews before your trip do so and make sure you specify the time period at which you will be present.

Finally, one of the bigger reason people struggle is because they either do not have enough experience , or they're not specialists in a field the local job market is interested in.
