No one ever said it to be easy. It's hard and it requires foresight and preparation. Even the MNC route isn't granted.
But it happens. People every year manage to succeed in doing that, and fortune usually favors the bold. If all you do is sit down in the comfort of your home and job and apply for job postings abroad with a foreign address, unwilling to do your interviews physically, with little to no investment in staying by forcing into others the fact that you speak english and the unwillingness of doing nothing else, there is literally no reason why they should hire you.
Not only sponsoring a visa can be a pain in the ass to the HR, you going there and realizing you didn't like the place and leaving after a year makes it so not worth it for them to even consider you.

You should also compensate for the difficulty of the endeavor with a good enough volume. If you're looking to go to Taiwan, do them all-Taiwan, Japan, Korea, China, HK and Singapore. Even the ones you don't want -who cares ? My friend who was in a situation similar to yours, applied to around 500 offers over the course of a year and got around 5 interviews, 2 of which resulted in a "yes".

Another had literally no fucking experience whatsoever but just happened to save some money and went on a 2 month trip in Taiwan after college to celebrate. My man had a job lined up by the end of the first month. That guy was smart however, had the great idea of hiring a professional translator to rigorously translate his CV and cover letter, and the guy just played up to the HRs.

As for me, the reason why i'm here is because i've literally tailored my studies to finding a job there.Double diplomas, internships... There's a lot of things you can do to get yourself wherever you want provided you think about it soon enough.

posts.com:
The Czech attitude towards pretty much anything is "I don't give a shit just don't bother me". That goes for weed, it's not technically legal there but there are tons of head shops and references to weed around Prague. I haven't tried getting any over there but I'm guessing you could ask in one of the head shops, or try your luck on a dating app. Otherwise bars like the ones already mentioned are a good bet. Whenever I've smoked weed in other European countries it's been from the Czech Republic and it was good stuff.

Brno is a cool city, not nearly as touristy as Prague. I stayed there for a few nights and went to Moravsky Krumlov to see Alfons Mucha's masterpiece on display in a 900 year old castle. Also the ossuaries are pretty wild.

Cesky Krumlov is beautiful, definitely recommend spending a couple nights there if you like old castles. Also Hluboka nad Vltavou is one of the most beautiful castles in the country and it's not far.

Pilsen is cool but definitely more of a "locals-only" vibe except in the touristy spots like the Pilsner Urquell brewery. The beer and food is pretty exceptional.

posts.com:
>>2391105
If you're used to USA or UK prices then the entirety of the Czech Republic will feel very affordable to you, unless you're trying to stay in high end AirBnbs/hotels and only eat at tourist trap restaurants. For $50 to $100 USD/night you should be able to find very comfortable places to stay in good locations, and I'm sure you can find cheaper stays than that if you really dig.

I think every single restaurant meal I ate in the Czech Republic was less than $15 USD, and that would probably get you an appetizer + entrée + at least one large beer. Otherwise, I would go to a grocery store in the morning and get some bread for like $1.50, some cheese for $2, some meat for $2 and some apples for $2 and be set for the day. Bus, train and tram tickets are extremely affordable, I don't think I've ever paid more than $10 and that was for a longer train ride.

In restaurants make sure you understand how tipping works - for example, after you ask to pay, the waiter will bring the card machine to your table, tell you that the price is 250 Kc, and then you have to say "please make it 300" or whatever you want. I think 10-15% is adequate for a tip there.

>>2390514
Český Krumlov is pretty, but full of Asian tourists
do not visit the Egon Schiele museum there, it is extremely disappointing bordering on tourist trap
imo it's worth it, but Třeboň is a similar experience with much less hassle, you can get amazing fresh fish from the fish farms, and still visit Krumlov for 1 day
>>2389763
you should definitely visit at least 1 castle and do a castle tour, I've been to 10+ and was never disappointed
some even have ren faire style larpers do shows in the castle grounds
people will recommend Karlštejn, the castle itself is nice but the town is a tourist trap, so visit literally any castle that isn't Karlštejn, Prague Castle or Krumlov
you should also go hiking, the ideal case is you make friends with colleagues and visit their "chalupa", or go kayaking/biking/camping in a tent if you're into that
in summer/autumn you can go mushroom picking and hopefully get invited by a colleague for ovocné knedlíčky (fruit dumplings) which is the best Czech food that you can't get in restaurants
you can also try going to the opera at National Theater or Estates Theater in Prague, tickets are very cheap compared to elsewhere, shows almost every night, and the opera houses themselves are really beautiful
even if you don't listen to classical music it might still be fun to mingle with a classy crowd
Black Light Theater is fun too
>>2393053
for Czech food, I like Na Rozhraní right next to Hradčanská metro and Rodr at Kobylisy metro
Potrefená husa is a decent franchise
the Italian place on náměstí Republiky is pretty good too
for desserts and coffee I like Černá madona (expensive but very pretty place) and Ovocný světozor
obligatory reminder that trdelník is not Czech and never will be

We have laws that after 10pm it must be quiet, so alternative public raves are a no no unless it is indoors or in a wasteland.

I don't personally do this kind of stuff but my friends are out every week on some weird ass rave.

You can try Bike Jesus on Štvanice island. It's kinda alternative and a good place to start when exploring the non-commercial scene.
There also used to be raves held inside a rusty old cargo ship on the river, but it might be closed during the winter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For those that have moved overseas or via plane, how did you handle getting your shit sent over?

I've currently packing the bare essentials and leaving boxes at my parents house that they can send over later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401584
I’ve done it two very different ways. The first time was broke and minimalist; I gave away or sold as much as I could, left a small number of things with friends, and shipped a very small volume of stuff—just a few medium-sized boxes. I went back to visit a handful of times and sent myself a few more items from the ones I left with friends, but it was really about stripping down at that point in my life.

The second time was part of a generous corporate relocation package. A bunch of dudes came to my house and packed literally all of my stuff, including a lot of furniture, most of it into a shipping container. Some was shipped by air and we had it inside of a week, most came a few weeks later by boat, when it was unpackaged for us by another crew. That was absurdly easy but probably costs more than you want to spend. There are international relocation companies that do nothing else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Sometimes it's easier to just fly things over yourself, i.e. by buying more checked luggage and visiting your family once or twice when you're settling in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401594
This is true, too—in both cases described above I used twice (or more) the checked baggage I normally would. When traveling solo or for a short business trip I like to avoid checked bags completely, but I had two medium-large checked bags the first time I moved abroad, and the second time, moving with wife and kids, we had something like six checked suitcases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401601
You just need to adapt a different strategy for buying tickets because sometimes a more expensive base ticket ends up to be cheaper because of lower fees for additional baggage.
An additional benefit is that you can leave many things behind and only bring them over once you know what you needed at your new location.

posts.sub: How do you stop your trip from feeling like a to-do list?
posts.com: Mine's feeling like a bunch of things I gotta just tick off now. Should I toss my itinerary and just fuck around?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2400008
Realize your itinerary is a wishlist not a must do. Understand you'll always forget something, delays will cause you to miss something, or powers that be have something unexpectedly closed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2400008
Do a longer trip and have exactly 1 thing planned for every day. Except for all day stuff like a day trip requiring a 2 hour train ride each way, you'll have all the rest of the day to fuck around after doing the 1 thing, and doing the 1 thing might give you ideas for new places to fuck around in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2400008
first time I went to Japan I went with no itinerary, the first few days I would just go take random trains and get lost for a few hours just walking and entering any place that seemed interesting. for the second week of the trip I looked up cool places to go / day trips from Tokyo on my phone (as in, I looked them up at the start of the second week of the trip, not beforehand)
I find that if you dont even have a list in the first place it can't feel like you're just ticking shit off a list, and if you're researching places to go once youre actually there it feels more like nice suggestions rather than a set schedule

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2400060
This seems like a great idea. Aside from the shit I gotta do in advance like sumo tickets or whatever I'll probably follow in your footsteps. Researching stuff when I'm already in Japan seems like it'll be more natural than like forced BS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2400079
as a disclaimer, this only works if you go to a small country or like Europe where "a day trip" gets you to any possible location within the country OR if you don't mind just staying around one city and its surroundings (in Japan's case, Tokyo).
if you're going to Japan too it's generally fine if you have like a very broad itinerary of where you're gonna be staying at (not what you're gonna do in each city but it could look something like
>Tokyo 7 days
>Osaka 4 days
>Kyoto 3 days
)
i was personally fine with just fucking around in tokyo for most of my trip because I didn't care much for Kyoto at the time, but for my next trips I researched some cool places beforehand just because Japan is way too big (for example theres enough shit to visit in Hokkaido and general Japanese northern area to fill up multiple 2 week trips depending on which season you visit). if youre an urbanite you will want to spend a lot of time in Tokyo for your first trip but if you wanna visit a bunch of different rural areas you will have to plan ahead slightly

Things like ending up on a rooftop bar ran by the Yakuza, being strongarmed into buying drinks. Walking through an old-town Tokyo marketplace and seeing where the Yakuza hang out. The ogre looked around and then approached me. It felt like an icy hand gripped my heart and began wrenching it. No. No. No, this can't be happening. She must have seen it on my face because she just stood there at my table for a moment or two while I was frozen in terror and anguish. She was morbidly obese and obviously very unwell.

The only thing she said to me was
>I'm sorry
and then shuffled off and back outside
she left a stink cloud behind, moldy clothes and body odor
I somehow didn't vomit, but my mind was breaking. I had built up this person so much in my mind over the years, and we had so many great times together gaming and talking on voice chat, we were basically inseparable and it became romantic. We had done lots of erotic roleplay and then phone sex and basically everything you could do short of video chat to video chat masturbation. She had insisted she was just too shy to do that.

I just sat there for a couple hours in a daze as my wondeful future shattered and everything came crashing down around me. I had invested so much time and energy into this woman. It broke me for about a year.

I booked through expedia. I don't know, this shit's a confusing mess. The first flight is a domestic US flight which is through united. The rest is through ANA. ANA won't let me check in because I need to checkin the first leg of the flight. UA won't let me check in because of this passport stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't have experience with this exact situation, but generally speaking —you really only need transit visas for extended layovers (12+ hours) and other circumstances.

On any given day there are like a billion people on brief layovers in Japan, if there was additional paperwork needed it would be incredibly brief and painless.

I guarantee that all they want to do is scan your passport at the desk, which is why you can't do mobile check in (they are inexplicably weird about that stuff sometimes). Just get to the airport early so you have extra time to sort it out.

You'll be fine. Have a pleasant flight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396592
1/2
Been several times, most recently in 2018 and summer 2022. Great city and quite cheap overall, here are some basic recommendations if you have a couple of days:

-Buda Castle, free and provides nice views of the city. You can often see the ceremonial Horse Guards do their rounds, which is fun. There is also a museum of Hungarian art within the castle grounds which is quite cheap and well worth seeing.
-Thermal Baths: if you can only do one, do Széchenyi. Its the biggest and has a nice variety of hot pools, cold/medium pools and sauna/steam rooms. When you arrive, don't get confused and think that its only an outdoor pool- you have to go indoors and look around to find all the pools. If you have time to do two, do Gellert as well, it is smaller but less crowded and in a prettier setting.
-Ruin Bars: there are several, the most famous is Szimpla, which will pretty much always be busy during drinking hours. Stroll around its area and you'll find others each with their own quirks, as well as a kind of Hungarian food court/area that tends to be around there.
-Orsokahz: Hungarian parliament, a really magnificent building. Even if you aren't interested in architecture or history this is well worth checking out, it dominates the skyline of the city and is just breathtakingly beautiful and magnificient, especially as you cross into the city at night and see it for the first time. You can only go in with a guided crowd tour, but its worth doing. Slightly expensive by Hungarian standards but not too bad, but be sure to book well in advance because English tours fill up.

Whatever you do, be sure to walk the banks of the Danube by Parliament and cross the Chain Bridge and Princess Margaret Bridge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396592
>>2396840
2/2

Other good stuff:

-Go the the Zwach distillery and get a tour, its cheap and they can get you pretty hammered if your guide is feeling like it. Zwach is also a very uniquely Hungarian beverage and there's rarely even anyone at the distillery. Fair warning: most people find regular Zwach pretty fucking foul, but the plum and coffee varieties are good shit. On the topic of food and drink, be sure to try the following: Tokay, which is Hungarian sweet wine, Langos fried flatbreads with toppings (go to Retro Langos for these), goulash, and Palinka (pear brandy which I personally think is foul but they like it).
-Gul Baba street, one of the steepest streets in major European cities, which ends with the tomb of an old Muslim theologian/scholar, also a pilgrimage site and rose garden.
-Citadela, where you'll see the big soviet statue, old fort that has the best views of the city and a nice hike to get up there
-Margaret Island, which is a cool island in the Danube with gardens and an assortment of stuff, good spot for picnics
-Fisherman's Bastion, which are the white fortifications you'll see, you can enter for free and if a turret/tower tries to charge for entry you can generally just come back at sundown and they won't be charging any more.

I think you can get to Bratislava by boat very easily from Budapest, but I've never been.
Don't take taxis, they are a literal cartel designed to scam people.
Also get some turkish food while you are there and use trams instead of the subway. The trams are great, run everywhere and are cheap, the subway fucking sucks, everything is ancient and last time I took it a train caught fire. Anyway I fucking love Budapest, I wish the Hungarian government could pay me to shill it on Tanzanian Hand-Looming Forums.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396840
>>2396848
I'm an expat living in Hungary, and while I don't particularly care for Budapest or the people in it, I do support people coming here and spending money. So, I offer a few corrections/elaborations--

>Ruin Bars ... Szimpla ... Hungarian food court/area
Szimpla is the most famous. It's going to be full or tourists, but I can imagine it's fun for young people. The "food court" is called "Street Food Karavan"-- it's at the end of the street that Szimpla is on. If you're at one end of the block, and there's no food court, it's on the other end. From Szimpla, if you keep going in the same direction, then turn left when the road ends, you'll pass by a nice brunch place called Cirkusz that is sadly crowded all the time, and then if you turn right you'll end up a Gozsdu udvar, which could also be described as a kind of food court area. If you put the names into a search engine, you should be able to see the locations.
>Orsokahz
Orszaghaz. Book the tour online and print out the tickets. I've heard it's great. If you're there, you might as well walk across Szabadsag ter. Check out the monument to the Soviet liberators of Budapest, the statues of Reagan and H.W. Bush, the old stock exchange (on your right), and the fortress-like US embassy (on your left). At the opposite end of the square, there's a memorial to the German occupation of Hungary. You can then continue ~200 meters along Oktober 6 street, pass by George Soros's university, and you'll soon be able to see the square in front of Saint Steven's Basilica. The basilica is pretty cool, but it's expensive to tour. There are a bunch of tourist trap restaurants in that area, but, if you're there around lunch time, I recommend hummusbar on Oktober 6.
>Zwach
Zwack is the distillery. The beverage is called Unicum. I don't drink it, but the closest commonly known drink similar to it would be Jaegermeister.
>Palinka
Palinka can be made from many fruits. It can vary in strength from ~20% to ~80%.

You can find a lot of information/guides on Google desu but I'll try to answer your questions.
>how do i find a good place to live
Lots of websites like booking.com or hostel world can help you find a place, although some would argue you might get better deals on websites directly. I wouldn't stress too much unless you're desperately trying to save money.
>how do i learn important customs in the place i visit/how do i not act retarded.
Again, google can help you. Wikivoyage usually has some tips but there are lots of websites.
>How do i plan my stay?
Look at websites like wikivoyage, lonely planet, tripadvisor etc. Make a list of must do things and some optional stuff if you gave time. Don't over plan it, you should be able to be spontaneous, you never know what might come up. In terms of time, I typically plan 3 or 4 nights per place I'm staying - it can be more or less based on how much time I estimate I'll need.
>then there are also issues like transport
Again, you'll need to use resource websites like wikivoyage. If you're interested in Japan, the Japan general thread has resources in the OP.
Also, not to overwhelm you, but don't forget to look into visa requirements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
>how to travel i have no idea wtf im doing
First thing's first, what's your budget (how much are you willing to spend total - $3000, $4000)? If you can't afford it then you can't go. Second, where are you going and for how long? You can split your budget by number of days and then check if you have enough money for accomodations, food, tourism, flight, transportation or if it will be unafforadble for you at which point you need to work more and delay your trip. You're from EU so that passport should open a lot of doors for you, some countries may still require you to apply for a visa so check before you buy a ticket if you need to or don't. Also, check restrictions on time limits for visa-free travel (can't go in visa free and stay indefinitely, many places have a 90 day limit).
>what about a place to stay?
hostels, airbnb's, cheap hotels, expensive hotels are all options. You want to focus on WHERE you want to stay. Staying "in tokyo" is not the same as staying "in akihabara in tokyo", you could be a massive distance apart from where you want to realistically spend most of your time. Look for accommodations within your budget in a zone you like, or just next to the zone you want to be in if it's not too far (or if public transport is close, available and reliable).
>what about customs?
dont need to know them for the most part, just know big ones (i.e. no alcohol in muslim countries, no drugs practically anywhere, no nudity in the streets) and just be polite. If you dress well and are polite, no one will bother you, if you fuck up a custom that people care for just apologize and ask for an explanation after telling them you didnt know. What you should know is that if strangers approach you for something, 99% chance its a scam. Strangers will help you, but usually only after YOU ask THEM for help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391466 (cont.)
>how do i plan my stay?
Research, and lots of it. You have the internet available, so use it. You can go minimalist and winging it or you can make a full day by day itinerary where you pick certain stops per day and plan a route to visit all of them. If you search online you may find sample routes for places you want to go to which you can alter at will based on your own interests. Look up lists of landmarks, museums, historical sites, hidden gems, hot spots in town and then find out which ones you want to go to and which ones you can skip on. Once you know where to go, find ways to connect them. If they're all in a circle around your accommodation, divide that circle into quadrants and explore it in a loop so you hit your interests and see the town on the way to and back. You can even find quality restaurants ahead of time per area and go to those the day you head out. It's really no different from mapping out a day in your own town. Something like:
>want to go see city hall in my small town
>oh and there's a museum a few blocks away
>there's even a really beautiful park further down from the museum
>it's going to be around lunchtime when I go, theres a restaurant with great reviews between the museum and park so i can stop there
>after the park i'll need to make my way back, but ill return in a circle instead of a straight line back to check out a church and another museum before I leave
It's that simple, people really overestimate planning for travel. It takes a few hours at most to have everything ready, from bookings to day-to-day itineraries.

Speaking of bookings, do not use sites that book for you. Always book directly with an airline/hotel. If there's a problem and you book directly, then the place that fucked you has to deal with you themselves. If a booking agency fucks up, then you don't deal with the hotel or airline, you deal with the agency, which means you're fucked because they won't give you a fix when you need it, only after.

If you're worried about losing your phone, ask for a physical map and have the hotel circle their location so you can show that to a cab driver.

>>2391137
> I know i would be completely fucked if i bought an airline ticket today and winged it
What makes you say that? It's not hard to 'wing it'. The only things you really need to make sure of are:
>Visa requirements
Just google Japan entry requirements for UK citizen or wherever you're from
>Money + money exchange access
I recommend opening a wise account, it's just a debit card you send money to that can pay in 99% of currencies with very low fees (like 0.5%). Avoid using your home debit card, it's probably going to charge a whole lot more than you expect. Using wise card at the ATM is a good idea too, since cash exchanges charge stupid fees.
>Somewhere to stay on your first night out of the airport
Well, you simply don't want to be caught with nowhere to stay.

That's it. You're going to Japan and Korea, both very safe countries, there's no secret shit you need to learn. There are no secret cultural customs you should learn. You're (probably) a white guy, the japs aren't expecting you to know which side of the road to walk on.

>>2391714

Japan has a renowned train network, it wouldn't be hard to get to other places, I'm sure there are a lot of great places outside of tokyo that you can get to easily. You definitely shouldn't try to do a whole tour of Japan with 10 cities in only 2 weeks, but 30 days is a very long time for a single place.

On top of this, and most importantly. Allow yourself to be spontaneous.
If you are staying in a hostel (which I highly recommend) and someone invites to do something, it's probably a good idea to go. If someone says there going to some other city and you think it looks like a good place, then you should consider joining them even if it wasn't in your plans. When you're on a holiday you can afford to do that, what else have you got to do, work?
There are two types of people that I HATE when it comes to travelling: picky eaters and over-planners, or people who are too scared to stray from their plan.

Just know where you need to be for your flights, that's important. You might have a few ideas of where you'd like to go, but be flexible, transport and accommodation might not always be in your favour. Or, someone you meet will show you a better location.

Being spontaneous on trips is fun, and it will teach you that every day presents you with millions of decisions, most people don't realise those decisions that they make.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391753
>Worried about people not speaking english
Google translate, just translate no more than 8-10 words at a time and use simplified english, it works better that way.
>I have to figure out public transport on my own
Typically easier than you imagine. I would be surprised if electronic ticket machines at train stations didn't have a button to display in English. Most developed countries have their public transport loaded on google maps, for longer bus rides that require privately owned transport, use rome2rio. A lot of cities have special 'bus card' things, I guarantee you can buy one of these at the airport with $15 pre loaded onto it.
>Aren't hostels expensive
Almost always cheaper than a hotel. I just searched for accommodation in tokyo on booking dot com and sorted by cheapest, the whole first page was all hostels. Besides, the opportunity to meet people by staying in hostels cannot be bought.

My other tip, take a backpack not wheeled luggage.

Basically Anon, you're 20 years old, you don't need the boring boomer-tier holiday where you have a private apartment your travel agent got you. What you need is a wild ride where you make last minute decisions, meet new people, leave them behind, go places you didn't even know existed, try foods you can't pronounce, walk through parts of the city where taxis don't go, have conversations with people you knew for 3 hours yet will remember forever and come back with photos that actually have interesting stories attached to them.
Would you rather show your friends back home a photo of a statue and say "this is just some old statue, I walked there and went home." or be able to say "I met these 2 american guys who were going to see this statue, so went and saw it with them. I really liked those guys, so I went with them to kyoto the next day."

did this at your age. went 3 weeks japan+korea and the backpacking to southeast asia. just got a flight to japan, then another to korea and from there to singapore. a few weeks before i booked an airbnb for the whole stay in korea and japan. just booking a hotel for a few days and then planning the rest after works too - i did it this summer in turkey. it was a bit stressful sometimes but it works. when i arrived in singapore at 6am in the morning without sleeping i had nothing booked or planned. literally had to find a hostel on booking.com while i was still at the airport but this worked out completely fine. the rest of the trip i pretty much planned on the go and everything worked out perfectly. traveling alone without planning much is one of the best experiences you ll have. in japan/korea you should probably plan a bit more tho. check what public transport is available and what kind of tickets are cheapest

what to bring aint deep: laptop, phone, cables, clothes, sunglasses, journal, a book, maybe a spare phone if you or a family member has an old one (for a sim card because you are likely to need your own sim card for bank/other accounts nowdays), laundry detergent for traveling, 1-2 thin towels, maybe some cash of the local currency, camera, dildo collection etc. etc.

also dont need to prepare anything really, just check if u need visa etc and maybe places where u wanna go. my tip is to go to hostels or do couchsurfing to meet new peope. find out what (dating) apps you can use to also meet locals. that s how you find out about places/trips you wouldnt have known before

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391717
>8k euros
good budget but depends on length of stay and luxuries you indulge in
>close to enough for 30 days in Tokyo?
I loosely planned a trip to Japan and found I'd spend around $5-6k on two weeks but $2k of that is the flight because burger. You really need to spend the time to crunch numbers because even though you have enough to go, you don't know if you have enough to go for 30 days. Some stuff will be more expensive too, so if you want to go to a ryokan or go to a hot spring town and get a hot spring hotel for a night, that will up pricing. You really need to budget before you go. As for 30 days in Tokyo, lmao you clearly didnt listen to us and try to plan shit out. You should be moving around since you're staying so long.
A good sample itinerary for you would be:
4 days Tokyo > daytrip to fuji > train to Kyoto and stay 5 days > train to Osaka and stay for 4 days > bus to the nakasendo trail and try to stay at a post town at the end of the hike > bus to Gero and stay a few days for hot spring relaxation > bus to takayama > daytrip to shirakawa-go > continue northeast or loop back to tokyo.

This is the way you should be thinking of your trip. You allocate days based on what you want to see per city/town and some time for travel within the country. The SIM card at the airport will be a must for internet on the go. Hostel vs. Hotel vs. Airbnb is subjective and depends on pricing. Some hotels are good and cheap enough to justify, especially if you like a private room and can be social without a hostel setting.

I disagree with bagpack only, i do wheeled carry on + normal sized bagpack (not the 55L shit) so that my clothes arent crumpled up messes on arrival and just keep it in my airbnb/hotel so I roam free and unencumbered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381428
It really all depends on your tastes, anon. But if you want the most bang for your buck, plan a trip to do two of these cities at the same time. For example, the ferry from HK to Macau is only 40 bucks (roundtrip) and Shenzhen is right at the border. So you could like, leave a day or two for visiting Macau and do the rest of the week in Hong Kong visiting the city, museums, the nearby greenery or simply just having fun. Same goes for Singapore and Kuala lumpur, a simple bus trip of a few hours gets you from one to the other.

Same goes for Japan. Kyoto and Osaka (+kobe) are basically the same city. only issue is if you want to do Tokyo too, in which case an overnight bus trip (500km) won't cost much. And Same goes for Seoul/Busan (300km)
Taking this into account, you can easily see that HK/Shenzhen/Macau is a great deal and so is Kyoto/Osaka/Kobe (kobe is definitely worth a visit !), especially if you can fit Tokyo into your timetable/budget. I'd also put Malacca/Kuala Lumpur/Singapore as another trio worth visiting.

On the other hand, there are places where it's worth just taking 2-4 weeks, find an appartment or airbnb to rent, and pretend you've lived there all your life. These places are Chongqing and Taipei, in my opinion. They're relatively peaceful places with not much shit to do but basically go on a walking adventure around the city, discover the people, hear their stories. Maybe have a love story. Maybe look at the job situation so you can make it there. Who knows.

Here's the Cyberpunk rankings of the cities I've visited so far:

Tokyo (7/10) (overated- too clean and tidy)
Seoul (7/10) (overated- has too much of a boring American "grid" like layout)
Busan (8/10) (underated- multiple skyscraper urban cores tucked in between mountains and hills filled with favela looking "slums", good mix of grit and modern/sleek)
Kyoto (0/10) (Asking if Kyoto is Cyberpunk is like asking if Florence, Italy is Cyberpunk. No.)
Jakarta (6/10) (too "low life" and not enough "high tech", its just a giant open sewer slum with some high end shopping malls in the center)

Some others
Bangkok (9/10) (100% Blade Runner/Night City, my favorite on this list, only reason its not a 10 is because I havent been to China yet which I imagine would take all perfect 10/10 rankings)
Saigon (8/10) (the "low life" aspect among neon grit is well represented, but a little lacking in the balance of modern infrastructure, skyscrapers and urban verticality outside of a very small area of District 1- give it time though, the city is building up fast and will probably take a 10/10 spot some day)

Keep in mind, this was all before COVID though- 2018 and 2019- and I imagine lockdowns killed any sort of that Cyberpunk "wild west", hustle and bustle feeling these places used to have. I imagine theyre all a lot quieter now and all the small businesses are mostly shuttered.

posts.com:
Some of the cities mentioned in this thread are too 'clean' to be cyberpunk. More like cyberpop. Look for cities that have large slums; the more populated the slums, the more likely it is to become cyberpunk, as the slums begin to stack on top one another. Bonus points if it's next to high rise skyscrapers in a densely packed area. Also, look at rapidly developing countries which are industrial & thus are very polluted. The destruction of the environment is a major trope in cyberpunk; places with lots of smog, terrible weather, rivers of trash, e-waste will definitely fit this.

Other tropes are the feeling of isolation in a densely packed area, orwellian surveillance and the 'sin city' factor, especially if it's open-air/ungoverned/state sanctioned.
Think the 7 sins:

Lust: escorts, massage parlors, love hotels, easy access p0rn, hypersexuality, gay bath houses, ladyboys
Gluttony: fast food, binge drinking, gold plated food, silver facials, excessive materialism/consooming
Greed: crypto, casinos/gambling, stock market, hustlers, gig economy, cash4gold, various scams, black market (silk road, organ harvesting),
Sloth: high automation, widespread apathy/nihilism, indifference to cruelty/bystander effect (watching people die, ignoring untouchables), promoting laziness
Wrath: war propaganda, political/ethnic/religious scapegoats blasted on media, eye 4 an eye mentality, cheering on violent/self-destructive behavior, sanctioned gangrapes, crimewave, gangs, police brutality, rudeness
Envy: sports cars, bling, expensive bags, photoshopped models, paradise packages, high rise condos next to slums, celebrities
Pride: social media, taking pride in degeneracy, ethno-narcissism, hyper-nationalism, religious zealots, promoting vanity

Which cities come to mind? Next time you re in a big city, look around for the 7 sins and tropes such as class disparity, pollution, industrialization, automation, overpopulation etc.

>>2400999
Personally I gotta say I didn't really like Medellin itself all that much because of the striking contrast of poverty everywhere in the city. Like, you go to Plaza Botero and it's so full of homelessness and streetwalking prostitutes it was rather shocking. Even around El Poblado I found plenty of unsavory characters and I honestly felt like I could be robbed at any moment.
The highlights of the trip to Medellin were the times I wasn't in Medellin itself. Guatape, Jardin, Santa Fe de Antioquia were so much better. Mind you, I'm not really a party person, so my opinion doesn't account for that kind of stuff.
Medellin does have a bunch of cool viewpoints as it's in a valley surrounded by mountains, I would recommend trying going up Cerro Pan de Azucar - easy to get to via metrocable, some 45 minutes of walking and you're on top, the walk didn't feel unsafe either and there were plenty of people chilling on top (pic related). Mirador el Cielo is also pretty good.
Didn't to the comuna 13 tour but I heard good things about it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2401084
El poblado is full of expats and backpackers and is entirely skippable if you're looking for an experience that doesn't involve acai bowls and overpriced beer. La setenta in laureles is a better nightlife.

Other medellin recommendations would be casa de la memoria and cerro de las tres cruces. My preffered bandeja paisa are la gloria de la gloria (envigado) and hacienda (near plaza botero).

Communa 13 is meh. Its become quite commercialised post-pandemic, but same with el peñol in guatape. Speaking of guatape, nearby San Rafael has good Charcos to take a dip in, although it would be a full day to do both.

>>2391474 (OP)
Moroccanfag here.
Morocco, and muslim countries in general, tend to give foreigners a lot of leeway because they understand the culture is different. They have millions of tourists coming every year, especially during the summer, and the ties with france and spain are particularly strong, historically, diplomatically and culturally too. The only thing they're not okay with is what they perceive to be obvious marks of disrespect. No faux pas will actually be taken personally by most locals. Morocco is the most liberal arab country there is.

In terms of public displays of affection, everything short of kissing is fine. You can hug your gf, hold her hands, etc. It's ok to talk to women, and since you're with your gf i'm guessing you're not going to be flirting anyway so it should be fine. To be perfectly honest, if you kissed, there wouldn't be a lynching either. A local would just call you out and that's it.

>what small things that aren't a big deal for us are frowned upon?
pretty much nothing. Except maybe one : there are liquor stores all over the place, and they usually sell you stuff in black bags or shit like that. Don't show alcohol on you. Also, a big hallmark of a tourist restaurant with high markups is that they sell alcohol. If a restaurant sells alcohol, i guarantee you'll see only foreigners in there.

BTW, don't have any pity towards the panhandlers, especially the pushy ones or the kids. They earn a lot of fucking money while the guys doing the real jobs don't get none and then they take that money to their parents who are basically pimping them out. Please don't perpetuate this.

I mean I don't know how long you have or what your priorities are. You'll find the friendliest people in the Tafraoute region, which has a cool African vibe. The most impressive area in the High Atlas is the valley between Imsfrane and Taghia, but it's not easy to get to, I had to hitchhike and walk.
Imlil is very impressive and easy to access, but keep in mind what >>2393147 says about scammers in touristic areas. Dades Gorge is great too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want beaches, south East QLD. Stay on the southern end of the Gold Coast (ideally south of Burleigh Heads). You can cross the border into NSW which has some of the best rated beaches in the country at Cabarita and Pottsville.

If you want city vibes, go to Melbourne.

If you want a variety of landscapes, go to Tasmania. Most of our mainland has beautiful but samey landscapes for hours on end, whereas Tassy you can see a variety within a few hours drive.

Avoid Sydney. Maybe a day or two to see the famous Harbourside shit, but it is a soulless bugman city. The conservative state government has squeezed any life out of it over the years, there's fuck all to do there now except gamble your pay away and buy overpriced shit. Everything Sydney can offer a tourist is done 4x better by the 3 places I've mentioned.

Personally if I had to spend 2 weeks here I'd spend 8 days touring Tasmania in a van and the rest chilling in Burleigh Heads or Coolangatta on the Gold Coast.

I've been travelling round aus for 2 months now. Keep in mind this country is straight up fucking huge. Like the size of the USA or China. Bit like hardly any people. Just "seeing the sights" as has been said before is like multiple day bus rides or planes etc.

And to be honest the cities in terms of being a tourist probably won't have much for you (don't get me wrong it's pretty cool walking round melbkurne or taking the ferry in sydney), but in terms of actually living here, like immigrating I've never been to a country more civilized or 1st world ever. I'm literally going to move here, probably melbkurne or sydney haven't decided. These big cities here are like modern, safe, good public transport, everything works on time, it's great and so easy. >Would you recommend visiting Adelaide?
Adelaide has fantastic food, an actual nightlife district (Hindley/Rundle St, but their sidestreets are where the real fun is, with heaps of fantastic cocktail bars, especially Peel St & Leigh St), and is very easy to commute around, along with being far cheaper than Melbourne and Sydney.
As far as beaches go, Adelaide has a lot of nice ones, though if you prefer warmer water and more of a beachside culture, then you'd want Queensland.
If you're coming to Adelaide, there's also a fair few worldclass wineries less than a half hour out of the CBD, and a great deal of great distilleries and breweries. If you're not a drinker, there's fantastic walking trails through the parklands and the Adelaide Hills. It's pretty easy to get to nature from Adelaide too.

>Sydney is pretty meh but go for a day or two if you want to check out Manly/Bondi and the harbour. Blue Mountains is cool, but can do Grampians in Victoria instead too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391812
Still here, still in India (although my wife and I are moving to the U.S. in the very near future).

Urban India is modernizing. Educated middle-class Indians have far better earning opportunities than their parents' generation. You'll find many younger people who live very Western-influenced lives. Nevertheless, these people represent a minority of the overall population, even in large cities.

Rural India is much different, and it's incredibly easy to find scenes similar to those depicted in the OP. I have very recently visited insurgency-affected regions of East-Central India wherein I met and spoke to tribal people who had never even heard of "America." It's not especially difficult to step away from modernity here.

I think, to a great extent, much of this "traditional charm" is directly correlated with socioeconomic inequality, poverty, and lack of educational attainment. India still has a distinctive culture, and this culture is apparent and practiced even in wealthier households. I live in a pretty middle-class neighborhood, and there's never a moment I don't doubt or realize that I'm in India (right now, for instance, there's a neighborhood mela and festival ongoing--I am being forced to listen to literally window-shaking devotional music while people scream, shriek, and dance on the road).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393667
cont.
As India's economy continues to somewhat strengthen, these visible indicators of inequality will--most probably--become less visible. But I don't think that's going to happen any time soon. India isn't going to magically transform into an unrecognizable destination overnight. The next several decades will doubtlessly bring some improvements, but I doubt India is going to become a Westernized or entirely modern country in our lifetimes.

(it's also worth noting that the current political landscape in many states is dominated by Hindu nationalist parties and politicians, almost all of whom are opposed to so-called Westernization, at least when such Westernization doesn't impact their personal earning opportunities)

>>2391822
In respect to clothes and whatnot: this is very, very prevalent, especially in rural areas.

I do think it's worth noting that Western dress among men is very widespread. Even villagers in the middle of bumfuck nowhere often wear t-shirts and jeans. Traditional dress isn't commonly worn except by persons working in certain professions and for special occasions (again, there are many exceptions--I haven't spent as much time in South India as I have elsewhere, but I think farmers and whatnot customarily and very regularly wear lungis. Lower-income Muslim men are another very noticeable exception, as many wear typically Islamic clothing).

(again, can't generalize. I wouldn't bat an eye at a guy wearing a lungi or dhoti in many neighborhoods. It's not uncommon at all)

The trend is different for women. Indian women in cities often wear "ethnic" clothing. Outside of cities, the overwhelming majority of women almost exclusively wear saris and other traditional garments.

>How will India combat the brain-drain of its most educated and talented citizen
I would imagine there's no solution other than the continued strengthening and reinforcement of the Indian economy.

I do have friends in their mid- to late-20s who earn the equivalent of $25,000-$40,000 per year with non-STEM degrees. You absolutely do not need to leave India if you're making that amount of money, given that that such an income is likely comparable to a low six-figure salary in most Western countries. However, while millions of Indians are higher-income earners, they still constitute a relatively small percentage of the overall population.

(of course, in the Indian context, any "small percentage" still translates to tens of millions of people)

Again, there's no easy solution. For many people in many industries, it's far too difficult to obtain a respectable salary. One of my brothers-in-law has a graduate degree and works as a tax specialist for a large, U.S.-based company. His American counterparts doing his job make $100,000-$125,000 per year; he makes $800 per month. Obviously many people in similar positions would leave if they had the chance.

Many Indians see Canada as an “easy P.R.” country. People who don’t have the credentials or qualifications to move to the United States or Europe often manage to get study or work visas in Canada. Once you’re there, you can sponsor just about anyone else to come over, provided you have the time, money, and resources. The end result is that Canada ends up with the immigrants who couldn’t make it anywhere else, along with all of their under-educated Punjabi and Gujarati relatives.

I do know plenty of normal, well-adjusted Indians in Canada. One of my ex-girlfriends lives in Calgary. She’s a reasonably nice, educated person. One way or another, I don’t really know why Indians who have other opportunities would bother with Canada, were it not for the easy visa. Most of my Indian friends with in-demand degrees and international work experience have said that the Canadian job market is hyper-competitive and that salaries are far lower than what you’d get doing the same work in America.

(of course, America has its own problems. IMO, the States get pretty top-quality Indian immigrants, with younger generations being much more willing to assimilate and intermingle with Americans than their boomer predecessors. The downside is that work-based green cards have country-specific quotas, so there are 15+ year backlogs. I know people who’ve done their PhDs in America, gotten good job offers, and haven’t even reached the point where they’re eligible to apply for permanent residency)
